It is signed George Harris. At that time I was contemplating taking proceedings for the rent, and bed given notice to quit to Herbert Smith, 194. At the bottom is written, "I acknowledge receipt on behalf of personal legal representatives of Mr. Herbert Smith. Signed George Harris." Smiths death is first disclosed in 193, dated May, 1905. The notice was December, 1904. I eventually received my rent. About Midsummer, 1905, the premises reverted to me. There was some difficulty in getting the last quarter's rent I understood

it was paid from Moorgate Street. I believe during the latter part of the tenancy the place was only re-presented by a young woman, who departed, and it was with the abject of getting my rent that she was followed to Moorgate Street. I did not see her at the police court. I do not think I ever saw her. I do not recognise any one of the defendants. (The Misses Oyler entered the Court.). I do not recognise those young ladies.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. I had an interview with a man I believed to be Herbert Smith, whose photograph I have re
cognised. I have certainly seen that face before. I cannot remem
ber that he told me the purpose for which he required the offices. There are still bankers and stockbrokers in Lombard Street.

FLORA MARY SMITH , widow of the late Herbert Smith, who lived at 11, Cedars Avenue, Walthamstow. I have lived there for 20 years. My husband was engaged in the tea trade in Mark Lane and had offices there. He became bankrupt about 1888. At two different periods after that he worked for his brother. He became ill in June, 1903, and died on October 22, 1903, in St. Bartholomew's Hospital The last day he went to work for his brother was June 22 or 23. He went to no business after that date; he was too ill. He passed through the City once, about July 7, on his way to the seaside. After
wards he returned home and then went to St. Bartholomew's Hos
pital. I have seen Ferryman twice since my husband's death. I believe my husband allowed him to trade under his name. My hus
band never carried on any business connected with stocks or shares. I saw Perryman at his office, 43, Moorgate Street. On both occasions he requested me to go and see him. I have seen Harris once, after my husband's death. On his death I telegraphed to Perryman, in
forming him, and received in the evening a letter from Harris enclos
ing £4 10s. in postal orders on Perryman't behalf. He said Perry
man was away from town and that they had arranged to send me the money. They knew my husband's death was impending. That was on October 22, 1903. Shortly after Christmas, 1903, I got a notice about some rent, and either wrote to Perryman or sent my son. At Perrvraan's request. I then went to 43, Moorgate Street and saw Harris, I think. I told him who I was and what I came about, and was ushered into Perryman's private office. Before going into the office I noticed a placard on the wall, "Herbert Smith, Stock and Share Dealer" or "Broker," or something of that kind, and five or six other businesses, or callings, underneath. My husband's name way in large letters. I think it was a registered letter I had from the solicitors on Christmas Eve saying would my husband give up the offices in the following June. The letter was addressed to Mr. Herbert Smith. I have not the document here. I saw Perryman in his office. I told him I wished him to take my husband's name out of the business, but he merely condoled with me on my husbands death. Nothing special transpired on that occasion. I merely said would he take my husband's name out, and he said he would. He said he would see to the rent. The premises in respect to which the

rent was claimed were 43, Moorgate Street I got this letter (pro
duced) in June, 1904, signed George Harris. That is the only one I have been able to find. I destroyed all the others when the name was taken down from the door. It it from 43, Moorgate Street. With reference to the sentence in it that he would rather tee me before I wrote to the bank, I had had a notice from the London City and Mid
land Bank. After I got it I wrote to Perryman and then got this letter, dated June 10, 1904. I then wrote letter 229 on June 27, 1904, to Perryman. The enclosure I forwarded was a further commu
nication about the rent of 43, Moorgate Street. Perryman made an appointment, and I went up to the office. I did not notice whether my husband's name was still up on the premises. I saw Perryman and asked him to take my husband's name out of the business. He said the business was my husbands. I said I was not aware of it, and he said, "Oh, yet, it was, and I have lost a lot of money by it." Then he said, "You being the widow, it really belongs to you." I declined to have anything to do with it, and said I would consult my brothers. He then said, "No, you are not to tell anyone anything that transpires in this office; it it strictly private." Then I said, "Well, take my husband's name out of the business and do not let me be troubled in any way again. Do not ask me to do anything or sign anything, or do anything in the matter." He assured me he would not, that it was finished, and I left him. I said, "Do not let any disgrace or dishonour be attached to my husband's name in any way whatever," and he assured me there should be none. Afterwards I heard the plate was taken down from the door and I thought the matter was settled, but in the following February I received a visit from the representative of Janson and Cobb in reference to 80, Lom
bard Street. I do not know that at any time my husband was the tenant of that office. (Letter 230 read.) The business was his brother's tea business. Harold was his brother. He is in the tea business still. The photograph shown to me is of my late husband.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. My husband had two brothers, Percy and Harold, "Vernon" was not another brother; I do not know who he is. I was married about 20 years. My hus
band told me of some of his business. I believe Harold dealt in stocks and shares, but nothing whatever to do with my husband. I did not know my husband carried on a tea business in partnership with Harold. Harold was originally his servant—he was nine years younger. My husband taught him the basined. From 1888 to 1902 my husband worked his tea business from home, taking orders through the post Then he did some outdoor business for Percy, who is a house agent. I should not think it took my husband a great deal in the city. He used to go out every day and come home about nine. My husband's signature is attached to Exhibit 190, the agree
ment which Dr. Bennett produced. The date is July 29, 1902. I knew Pern-man had an office at 80, Lombard Street. My husband baa offices from Dr. Bennett, but they were at 43, Moorgate Street. I have got them confused between 80, Lombard Street and 43, Moor-gate

Street, perhaps. My husband had one office only. That is all be told me about. My husband did not tell me everything he did. I telegraphed the news of my husband's death to Perryman because he asked me to keep him acquainted with the state of his health. I sent the telegram to 43, Moorgate Street. I knew my husband was in the habit of going there. It is not a fact that nearly all the money that my husband made in the last few months of his life was made by odd jobs that he did in stocks and shares; he knew nothing what
ever about stock and shares and never dealt in them. It was not £4 15s. 9d. I received, but £4 10s. It was for funeral expenses. I suppose, certainly not for rates of 43, Moorgate Street. I under
stood it was to help me in my trouble. The rates of my private house were about £6. My husband died on October 22. He was quite incapable of drawing cheque No. 92313 for £4 15s. 9d., as suggested to me. on that date. Matthews, of Matthews, Matthews, and Good-man were his cousins. Their office is at 32, Queen Victoria Street. I do not know anything about his doing business with them. Cowan and Sons, of Queen Victoria Street, were printers. I believe my husband did business with them. My husband passed through the City on June 22; he did not tell me he was going to the City to get money to enable him to go to the seaside He was away from home. He went to stay with a relation. Scarlet fever broke out in the family, anile, therefore, he could not return home, but went to the seaside from there. I did not want to take the fever home to my two children, so I could not see him at all. I believe Perryman gave him some money and told him he looked very ill and had better go to the seaside. I believe he gave him £5 or £2. I do not know exactly the sum. I wrote four years ago to Perryman with regard to taking my husband's name out of the business—Christmas, 1903, and I believe I asked him to do so each time I saw him. In June, 1904, I wrote. "I think it would be better not to trade under my husband's name." That was a mild way of putting it. There had not been an arrangement. I did not know that the business was carried on under my husband's name and that I was to be interested in it. If I could have afforded legal advice I should have taken it and compelled Parkman to take my husband's name down, but I had not the money and therefore I was obliged to let it remain until he chose to do it. I know nothing of Tyler; I never heard the name until I heard of his arrest. Janson and Cobb sent a registered letter to my husband for the rent of 43, Moorgate Street, not knowing he had passed away Perryman took offices in my husband's name at 43, Moorgate Street long before my husband died. My husband allowed him to trade under his name there. I do not think he had a share in the busi
ness. I think he had very little. Perryman gave him something when he thought he would, and very little it was. I told Perrvman I thought it averaged £I a week. I do not feel very friendly towards Perryman. He tried to ruin me. I have a good deal of ill-feeling towards him now. He tried to ruin me by trying to get me to take over the business. My relations with my husband were not the hap
piest.

My husband told me some things he did. He could not keep much to himself. I got it out of kern. He did not complain that his home was very unhappy in consequence. It was poverty that made the home uncomfortable. The detective, Maclean, called on me in reference to this matter. I did not tell the police I felt very bitter against Perry man. I told the officer that he had tried to make me take over the business. I had not the remotest idea of taking it over, and I was very unhappy that he should suggest it to me.
Cross-examined by Mr. J. Wellesley Orr. I only saw Harris once. My husband used to leave home about 8.45 a.m. and return at 9 or 10 p.m.

Re-examined. I did not get any part of the £26,000 that went into Herbert Smith's banking account. I only know that he allowed Perry-man to use his name. My husband said something about 80, Lorm-bard Street, but then he went to 43, Moorgate Street. He said Ferryman had an office at 80, Lombard Street. My husband's name imp not up there, I think. In the letter which enclosed the £4 10s. Harris condoled with me and said that Ferryman was away from town and that it had been arranged, as they knew my husband's death was impending, to tend me that money. Nothing was said about rates nor about a share of the business; it was purely a private matter. My husband was incapable of signing cheques quite six weeks before hit death.

To Mr. Justice Lawrence. Before my husband went to the seaside he was staying with a relation about a week. Before he went to that relation he had been living at home. He was always pushed for money. He has lost a lot of money. He had £800 from hit father in the tea trade and lost that. Between the time that he lott hit money in the tea trade and the time that he was taken ill he was not in well-to-do circumstances. He was in very bad circumstances.

PERCY SMITH , house agent, 87, Grosvenor Road, Highbury. The late Herbert Smith was my brother. He failed in 1888, and before he came into my permanent employment I gave him some employ
ment for a short time. He was in my employment continuously from May, 1902, till he what taken ill in June, 1903. Hit hours were from nine or 10 a.m. till seven or eight p.m. He came every day to my office. He acted at canvassing clerk. I gave him 4s. a day and a commission on business results. He was taken ill on June 22 and never came back to work. I have no knowledge of his being con
nected with any 'basinet in stocks and shares at all or having any such transaction.
Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. I did not know he had anything to do with an office at 80, Lombard Street. His work for me occupied the whole of his time from 10 till 8.

FRANK RICHARDS , clerk to Messrs. Dore and Sons, Limited, tailors, 43, Moorgate Street. The upper part of those premises is let in offices. I know the name of Dacre Tyler at being the ostensible tenant of those premises. I could not identify him. I recognize George Harris. I have seen him at those offices. I never remember

him personally handing rent to me. We received rents through our agents, Hobson. Richards, and Co. I have seen Perryman at the office and have known him by repute as Herbert Smith. He has been pointed out by various people. In 1900 there were some companies' names up—the Raudepoort Gold Mines Company, or Gold Mining Company, and the Hannan King Brownhill Gold Mining Company. About May, 1902, the name on the door was changed to "Herbert Smith, Mining Market Review." There was no description of the business. The companies' names had been taken away. The name of Herbert Smith remained there until the expiration of the tenancy in March, 1905.

Cross-examined by Mr. J. Wellesley Orr. I saw Harris in the office fairly often. I have handed him letters. I knew nothing about the firm. Some letters were addressed to Harris. Some were ad
dressed straight to him, and not c/o the firm.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. I have had Perryman pointed out to me at various times by different people both as Perry
num and as Herbert Smith. At the police court I said, "I would not swear to having seen Perryman, but I believe I have." I understood he was Perryman, but he was pointed out to me as Herbert Smith at various times before these criminal proceedings.

ALFRED DULIEU , waiter at Pimm's Restaurant, Cheapside. I recog
nise Perryman and Harris, and have known them by those names. I do not recognise Tyler. I have two nieces named Jessie and Annie Oyler. Some years ago they were out of employment, and I spoke to Perryman about Jessie, It might have been three years ago, and he said he would try to get her employment. Some time later he asked me if she was still out of employment, and when I said "Yes" he told me to send her to a certain address, which he wrote down on piece of paper. I believe it was in Moorgate Street. I do not think I spoke to Perryman after that about Annie. I got employ
ment for her at the Cellular Underclothing Manufacturing Company. I do not think Annie was ever employed at 80, Lombard Street. In the early part of 1907 Jessie again wanted some employment, and I asked Harris if he knew of an opening, and he said he would see. I approached him again on the matter, and he said he thought be might start her in a few days. I wrote down the address and gave it to my niece. It was Tokenhouse Yard or Buildings, to the best of my recollection.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. The detective Ottaway has been to see me. He told me the name of Perrvman in the first in
stance. Before that I called him "Mr. Fatty," of course not to his face. There are hundreds of customers whose names we do not know for years. I identify him as "Mr. Fatty" and as Perryman. He never had a conversation with me on business matters.

JESSIE OYLER , Spitalfields Market, waitress. In 1903 I was seek
ing employment and spoke to my uncle Dulieu, and after some little time he gave me a slip of paper with an address on it, Herbert Smith, 43, Moorgate Street. I went and saw Harris there, and said I had

come about the situation, and had been sent there by my uncle. He said, "Step inside." I took of the situation there and then at 10s. a week. I was employed by Harris, who I then took for Herbert Smith. I was employed to address envelopes; nothing else. I sat facing a window with my back towards the door. I got the addresses for the envelopes from lists provided by Harris, I do not remem
ber whether they were people living in London or the country. Miss Mabel Long was also employed there, and no one else that I can remember. She was in and out all day. There were two rooms in the offices. Miss Long shared one with me when she was there and Harris used the other. No one else used it. I saw no one else there but Harris. People could get into that other room from the corridor without my seeing them. I knew Harris as Herbert Smith, but I heard others call him "George," so I called him George. He answered to that name. I do not remember ever ceiling him Herbert Smith. I remained there about 12 months. My salary was increased up to 12s. a week. Shortly before I left Harris sent me across to 80, Lombard Street, to the Lombard Financial Corporation. I saw Mist Mabel Long there. I did not do any work there and do not know what I went for. I stayed there doing nothing. I may have read a paper or something. I had that arduous duty about a fort
night or three weeks, and left because I was ill. Alter a rest of two or three years I wanted further employment in March of this year. I left there about the spring of 1904. My sister Annie was looking out for a situation when I first went to 43, Moorgate Street, and she went with me there. She was employed at 80, Lombard Street, and was in the office at the time I was. We were at 80, Lombard Street together. I did nothing and she did nothing. In March, 1907, I went to my uncle Dulieu, and from what he said I went to 2, Token house Buildings and saw Harris and asked for Mr. Tyler. I did not see Tyler then, but shortly afterwards. I told Harris I had come about the situation and he said, "Wait for Mr. Tyler." I saw Tyler and went with him to offices at Pinner's Hall, two offices on the ground floor, an inner and an outer. It is possible to get into the inner office without going through the outer one. I was in sole charge of that office, and addressed envelopes from lists to people in the country, about 200 a day. I left them on the table and do not know what was done with them. My salary at Pinner's Hall was 12s., and my hours 10 till four. Tyler arrived before me in the morning. The letters were attended to before I got there. Tyler was in the office every day, but he would go away. Harris would come there daily, sometimes with Tyler and sometimes alone. I had instructions from Tyler that if anyone came for him and he was in I was to tell them he was out, which I did. People did not come very often. Tyler was seen by clients sometimes. I do not remember any of their names. Tyler would tell me to admit some people, giving me their names. The name on the office was "William Tyler and Co." There were no books in the office. There was not a letter book. There was a copying press, but I never saw a single letter

copied in the place. I was there about two months. Then I asked for more wages and Tyler said he could not give them to me. Harris said, "Would you care to come with me if I gave you more?" and I said, "Yes," and went with him to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, re
ceiving 15s. a week for addressing envelopes from lists provided by Harris to people in the country. There was an inner and an outer room in those offices, and one could get into the inner room without going through the outer one. The names up were, "The Financial Guardian" and "Raudepoort Gold Mining Co." I do not know who "The Financial Guardian" was. If anyone called about it Harris would see them. He went by the name of Harris. There was an
other young lady in the office, Miss Long, and one day a gentleman came in dressed up at though ill, and she said that was Herbert Smith. Then I asked, "Who is George?" and she told me. No one Asked for anyone by name at the "Financial Guardian." They asked if anybody was in who had to do with "The Financial Guar
dian." Miss Long and I were there together about three weeks, and then she left, and I have not seen her since. I do not know her hand-writing. I do not remember anybody asking for anyone but Harris. Harris used to use the letter books. Tyler used to come daily and stay half an hour or an hour, and longer sometimes. He came with Harris. Ferryman used to come there and ask for Harris, and if he was in he would go into him. If not he used to go outside and wait. People could go into the inner office without my seeing them. Perry-man only came now and again. I saw no circulars whatever at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, and I did not put any circulars into envelopes there. At Pinner's Hall I did. I never opened one to see the name. Tyler gave me the circulars to put into envelopes. They were already folded. I never heard the name of H.K. Ablett at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. I have heard the name of George Martin. Somebody came and asked for George Martin. Harris was in the office at the time and he saw him. I referred him to Harris, saying I knew nothing about it, and Harris saw him. I never heard the name of J. Wood at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. I never saw circulars at 80, Lombard Street. I never saw any gentlemen there at all, nor did I ever hear the name of Fraser. I saw no man employed there. I was still employed at the time of the arrest at the beginning of June this year.
(Tuesday, October 29.)

ANNIE OYLER , 117, Commercial Road. In 1903 I was engaged by Harris at 43, Moorgate Street as clerk at 8s. a week, my duties being at 80, Lombard Street. I was there about 12 months, from nine a.m. to four or five p.m., and occasionally took the letters to 43, Moorgate Street, Mabel Long generally taking them. There were sometimes callers seen by Long. I do not know what was said. If she was not there and anyone knocked I did not answer the door. I never saw Fraser nor heard his name mentioned. Harris came once or twice and saw Long. I never hoard what he said. There were

ledgers at Lombard Street, but I never looked at them. I and my titter were paid at 80, Lombard Street. (The Judge stated that the witness manifested hostility.) I made a statement to Ottaway. I said that Long brought my wages from 43, Moorgate Street—Miss Long told me to. I Have no recollection of laying that upon the door of one office was painted, "Mr. Fraser. Private." I never mentioned Fraser's name. I did not say that no books were kept there. I did not say that several persons called and complained of not receiving money due to them and that I told them Mr. Prater was out. I did not look to see how the letters were addressed. I did not tell the police inspector they were addressed to Fraser, of the London and Financial Corporation.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. Ottaway asked me some questions and wrote something down, which he read over to me. He did not ask me to sign it I did not say that people complained of not receiving money. I have told you everything I know.

HORACE SPENCER , 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, auctioneer. On February 24, 1903, I let offices in 2, Tokenhouse Buildings to James Wilkes Hawkes at £75 a year under agreement (produced), witnessed by George Harris. I received the rent sometimes by cheque and sometimes by cash, very often from Harris. The name put up was the Rand Roodeport Company. I saw Hawkes at the police-court In taking the offices he referred to Perryman. Ferryman said he thought Hawkes would make a good tenant, and, at far as the rent was concerned, that would be all right, he (Perryman) would pay it Cheque (produced) for £56 5s. of January 16, 1906, payable to me, is signed "C.W. Perryman"; that is for three quarters' rent to Christ
mas, 1906. Receipt to J.W. Hawkes is my handwriting. On March 20, 1906, I wrote to Perryman for the rent to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, and also to his private address. I wrote again on March 29 and April 20. I received cheque of March 24 for £18 15s., signed "C.W. Perryman." At Christmas, 1906, I lei another room to Perryman. £80 was the proper rent, but I let it to him for £40 temporarily, he to do all repairs and give it up at a week's notice. I produce cheques of February, 1907, for £10 and April 10 £10 rent for that room.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. Hawkes is a real person. Perryman had an office from me some years before at 4, Tokenhouse Buildings, and, not knowing Hawkes, Perryman promised that he would see the rent paid—I do not say that he guaranteed it, or that I had a legal claim against him.
Re-examined. I have known Perryman about ten years—I had not seen Hawkes before I let the premises to him. I think Hawkes made some payment in cash.

HENRY LOCKE SMILES , 79 £, Gracechurch Street, solicitor. I have known Tyler more than 15 years. On June 25, 1906, he and Perry-man saw me about an office which my firm had to let. I had also tome office furniture. They agreed to take the office at £40 for the remainder of the year, and to take the furniture for £10. They

took possession and then, owing to a difficulty with the landlord as to under letting, the offices were given up. On October 24. 1906, Ferryman wrote from 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, stating, "You will see that the office affair has been settled up long ago. You asked Mr. Tyler to terminate his tenancy, which he did, releasing my guarantee." I wrote to Tyler, on July 16, "I think that you might get Mr. P. (Perryman) to pay up to £5—that was for the furniture.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. The tenant to whom I had let my offices had the brokers in. Perryman instructed me to settle Memorandum of Articles of a company for which I sent a bill of costs and which he declined to pay. A small sum was subsequently paid. Tyler was very angry at having to give up the offices, and offered to lose £2—the money agreed for the furniture.

Cross-examined by Mr. Smith. I had had business relations with Tyler for nearly 20 years, and in his absence for six years in South Africa I held his Power of Attorney and received moneys on his account. I have attended to many legal matters for him.

SAMUEL HUNT , manager to Hunt and Co., office furnishers, 11, Bell Yard, Gracechurch Street. On July 3, 1906, I received instructions to remove and store office furniture from an office at 79 £, Gracechurch Street. It was pointed out to me by Tyler, stored by me till Octo
ber 9, 1906, and then removed to Pinners Hall, where my first painted up the name of "William Tyler and Co." (To Mr. Marshall Hall. I do not know Perryman.)

EEDMUND BULL , chartered accountant, 10, Old Jewry Ohambers, stated that he had the letting of Pinner's Hall, and in September, 1906, let two rooms to Tyler. £90 was asked, £80 was offered, and finally £85 was agreed upon.
To Mr. F.E. Smith. I obtained two references before the rooms were let, one from Messrs. Jack and Co., Copthall Avenue, and the other from Mr. F.H. Parker.

HENRY HEATLEY , lithographic artist, Spoke to calling several times at the office of William Tyler and Co., Pinner's Hall, but was never able to see anybody but a young lady clerk. He made verbal ap
pointments to see Mr. Tyler, but was never able to keep any of then. He explained by letter that he was writing for a friend in Ireland.

MISS CLAIRE LATUS , at present living at Portland Mansion, Clap
ham, and an actress. About the middle of April I was introduced to the firm of Tyler and Co. by a friend, and acted as lady clerk to them in April Rind May. I had bad office experience. I was engaged by Mr. Tyler at a salary of 12s. a week. I was to do typewriting and attend to the office generally, and the office hours were to be from half-past ten to half past four or five. For about a fortnight I was the only lady clerk, and then a Miss Ruby Reece came. I typed letters and addressed a lot of envelopes and circulars, arranged them and got things in order a bit. All these things had to be straightened out and that took nearly a day. The letters were dictated to me by Mr. Tyler. The number of circulars I dealt with might have been anything between 300 and 500. After I had done the envelopes

they were repacked in boxes. I saw some printed circulars like those (produced) on the table and deck in the office. I did not see any-thing done with them. I did not notice that different persons who came into the office took them off the counter. Sometimes Tyler was there before I was. My instructions were to take the names of callers if they would give them and any message. On one occasion I recollect that I said Mr. Tyler was not in when he was in. That was because the caller had refused to give his name. Tyler did not re
main in the office all day; he came in and went out. I did not keep say books of account nor did I see any. There was no pries copy letter-book, but there was a copying press. So far as I know it was never used. I have seen prisoner Harris at the office. I think be only came about twice, not many times, I know. I was there altogether four or five weeks, and only remember seeing him two or three times at the outside. Only on one occasion he gave instructions about letters he wanted typed. During the absence of Tyler, at the request of Harris I paid cheques into the bank. Harris asked me to endorse the cheques. I recog
nise the list produced as one from which I got the names and ad
dresses. I did not notice at the time that they were mostly people living out of London, but I see now that it is so. The list is called the "London and Provincial Investors' Register." Several names are struck out, and against these are the initials "G.A." (Gone away.)
To Mr. Marshall Hall. I said before the magistrate: "I do not know Pernyman." I do not know him.

To Mr. F.E. Smith. Tyler came to the office every day with one exception. The letters I wrote were mostly written in longhand and I copied them. A few boxes of the addressed envelopes were taken away by Mr. Tyler. The others remained in the office. I have scratched out one or two of the names where the letters have been returned.

THOMAS CHEESEMAN , manager to Henry Langridge, 16, Great St. Helen's. I know prisoner Tyler as tenant of two room at that ad
dress. He became the occupier of them in September, 1906, at £120 a year. The name up was Gibbs and Tyler, or Tyler and Gibbs, I forget which, and there were two names on the first floor windows, I forget what they were now; they were the names of companies. The £30 rent for the Christmas quarter of 1906 was paid by cheque drawn by "C.W. Perryman" on the London City and Midland Bank, Victoria Street. It is endorsed "W.H. Tyler." Since the arrest of Tyler at the end of May Perryman has called at the office to inquire if there were any letters for him. I referred him to the housekeeper, who always sorted the letters and gave them to the various tenants.

JOSEPH STEAD , private secretary to the Earl of Kilmorey. In April of this year I received a letter from Gibbs and Tyler fol
lows: "Dear Sir,—Fullers Earth Union, Limited.—We have an in
quiry for some founders' shares in this company, and we shall be glad to hear if you are desirous of selling your shares and what price

you will accept for prompt cash." I replied asking the price that Gibbs and Tyler offered, and, in reply to a telephone message, said that Lord Kilmorey would sell a founders' share for £50 net cash. I prepared to transfer from Lord Kilmorey to Gibbs and Tyler and sent the transfer with the certificate by Miss Cecil to Gibbs and Tyler's office with instructions not to leave the transfer unless she got the money. She brought back 10 £5 notes. Some of the notes were produced at the police court.

Miss
AMY CELL , clerk to Mr. Stead, gave corroborative evidence.

LEWIS JAMES WESTLAKE , Messrs. Pope and Westlake, stockbrokers, George Street, Bath. In May, 1907, we were desirous of purchasing a founders' share in Fullers Earth Union, Limited, for a client. On April 23 we received a letter from Perryman offering to sell a founders' share at £125 net. We replied offering £70, and Perry-man wrote back that he would take £90, to which price we even
tually agreed.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. We circularised a great many people in respect of these shares. Perryman's name was on the list of original holders. When we sent out the circular the dividend had not been declared, and we anticipated a very great rise in value It was a good gamble. We were willing to give £85 or £90 for a share; and if Perryman could have got a share for £50 and sold it for £90 that would have given him a good profit, the ordinary idea of good business being to buy cheap and sell dear.

NICHOLAS JOHN BLOOMER , manager of the London and Provincial Investors' Register, 13, Finsbury Street. It is a part of our business to supply lists of probable investors in town and country. They are mainly made up by searching the shareholders register at Somerset House, who are classified according to their addresses and the charac
ter of their securities. I know Tyler and Harris. Harris was ap
parently acting manager and confidential clerk of the "Financial Guardian." Besides supplying lists I did some business for him in the way of printing and folding, addressing and stamping circulars I was always paid in cash, com, or notes. I have been doing work of this kind for the "Financial Guardian" for about 18 months, the amount of money received being £159 16s. 4d. It was either in the name of George Harris or the "Financial Guardian." Harris never pretended to be the principal. I have known Tyler a year this month. Harris introduced him as a friend in a line of business similar to his own. What Harris was it is difficult to say. We get a lot of cus
tomer from that particular style of business which deals in shares, outside stockbrokers' business, and they all vary in detail. Harris's business was apparently that of dealing in shares, judging from the circulars printed. I also did work for Tyler—printing, addressing, folding, enclosing, stamping. Including stamps, the work done amounted to £389 18s. 3d. We sometimes had envelopes ready directed from Tyler and Co., small parcels, but not large numbers. We did not supply him with lists of shareholders. In April of this
year 145,000 circulars were sent out for Tyler. Payment was made both in cheques and cash.

THOMAS PARKINSON , manager of the Argus Printing Company, Temple Avenue, Tudor Street. I know defendants. I got to know Perry man about eight years ago, and the company has been doing printing for him since that time. He was then connected with the "Mining Herald, in old Jewry, which we printed. Harris was the "second" (clerk) in the "Herald" office. Perryman paid the ac
count by cheques. Afterwards Perryman was to be found at Herbert Smith's in Moorgate Street. I also saw Harris there. The photograph produced is not the Herbert Smith I was introduced to. He was dark, about 27 years of age, and had a black moustache. This would be about 1902. I was introduced to Herbert Smith by Perryman. I printed circulars for Smith. We did not set up the type. The formes were sent and we only did the machining. We had the formes from Bleach, printer, of Sumner Street. Harris gave orders as to how many to print, and the accounts were paid by cheques drawn by Herbert Smith, until the guarantee by Perryman in Sep
tember, 1904. I asked Perryman for the guarantee because we were not getting paid. The original was handed to Messrs. Lewis and Lewis. I had nothing to do with it after I had passed it into my directors' hands. After the guarantee Perryman always paid—by cheque. In all £931 4s. was debited to Herbert Smith. We also did printing for Messrs. Chalmers and Cox, for which Harris gave the orders. We had £55 from Cox. Chalmers and Cox were introduced by Perryman. I should not have given them credit otherwise. If they had not paid I should have looked to Perryman. We also did printing for A.W. Fraser, of Lombard Street. Fraser used to pay by cheque. In all the account was £376 9s. 6d., and in this case also Harris used to bring the orders. I never had conversation with Perryman about Lombard Street and Fraser. The printing was of the same character—circulars; but I never read them. We did not do any printing for "The Financial Guardian." We did printing for Tyler and Co. to their order. Tyler was introduced, I think, in 1905. His account was £304 4s. I had no conversation with Perry
man about Tyler and Co. The delivery note produced shows that in March of this year I was directed to deliver some circulars of Tyler's to "The Financial Guardian." The cheques produced from August, 1905, to August, 1906, are drawn to my company by Perryman. Mr. Perryman's guarantee did not become operative until January, 1905. The company afterwards brought an action against Perryman, Messrs. Lewis and Lewis acting for them. Judgment was signed, and Perry
man was served with a notice in bankruptcy at the suit of the Argus Printing Company for £351 14s. 9d.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. Perryman introduced a very large number of customers, and the accounts had been duly paid, but in September of 1904 there was money due from Herbert Smith which I could not get. I then went to Perryman and told him I had got into trouble with my board of directors for giving credit to Smith,

and I that my board objected to giving credit on any printing orders over a certain amount, and it was then that Perrynian gave me this so-called guarantee: "My dear Paikinson,—I am sorry to learn there is a balance due your firm on the three accounts introduced to you, and I will make it my business to see that they are stirred up to settle. In any event, you need not worry that the accounts will not he eventually promptly settled, because I will myself be answer
able for them, and if they are not paid before the end of the year I will pay them myself." Therefore the obligation with regard to pay
ment did not arise until the beginning of 1905. I do not know that an action was brought against Perryman and judgment obtained and that a bankruptcy petition was subsequently heard and dismissed, the allegation being that Mr. Perryman was trading as Herbert Smith. I do not know that in the bankruptcy proceedings the company recovered nothing as against Mr. Perryman.

Cross-examined by Mr. Leycester. I understood that the business at Moorgate Street was managed by Herbert Smith and that he had some money in it. He introduced three accounts to me—Chalmers and Cox, Fraser, and Herbert Smith.
Re-examined. I received from Herbert Smith £931 4s. 7d. in all. Perryman introduced about six accounts to me.
CLIFFORD BEARD , M.R.C.S., medical officer to the Fever Hospital Islington. Ruby Reece it a member of our staff, is suffering from malignant tonsillitis, and is unfit to travel.
Ruby Reece's deposition at the police-court was read.
Mr. PARKINSON, recalled. Some of the work Perryman introduced to me was company work—not Stock Exchange Work.
CLAIRE LATUS , recalled. (To Mr. Smith.) The day before Tyler was ill he gave me instructions to give hit letters to Harris, who came for them.

WALTER GEORGE BLEACH , 43, Broke Road, Daltton, printer. I have known Perryman and Harris for about 17 years in connection with the "Financial Observer," of which I did the printing for about 18 months, getting the copy at a rule from a lady clerk at the office at Jewry Chambers. The money was usually left out for me. I have seen Perryman there, but I looked to Harris for the money. I met Tyler at the office of the Rand Roodepoort Company, 43, Moorgate Street. I used to work for the company. The name of Herbert Smith what afterwards put up at 43, Moorgate Street. I have seen Perryman and Hawke a there occasionally. I have printed circulars, for Herbert Smith, the copy being handed me by Harris or a lady clerk. Perryman approached me in 1905 about starting another paper called the "Financial Guardian" and asked me if I would print it and take an office for it, which I did at 27, Sun Street. I got the type on the hire system. Perryman paid me the rent of the office and the type. The paper was only set up twice—it was never printed or issued. The manuscript consisted of cuttings from the financial papers, which I received from Harriet or a lady clerk. Cir
culars

(produced) in the name of H.K. Ablett and George Martin were printed by me at Sun Street in quantities of 2,000 to 4,000. I delivered them to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, and received payment from Harris or a lady clerk generally in cash. I think Harris ap
proached me first and asked if I would put up the name of Herbert Smith at Sun Street and take in letters. This was in February, 1905. I asked Perryman if I should do so, and he said, "Yes." The name was put up, and I received letters and took them to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. If callers came I was to tell them Smith was away, which I did. Bundle of circulars (produced) of the London Financial Cor
poration, 80, Lombard Street, were printed by me. I received in
structions at 43, Moorgate Street, from Harris or a lady clerk, or from Perryman. Bundle of circulars of Chalmers and, Cox, 2, Token-house Buildings (produced), were printed by me, on the instructions of Harris, Hawkes, and, I believe, Perry man, at 43, Moorgate Street I have known Hawkes for 10 or 12 years, when he was on the "Finan
cial Observer." I took him for one of the firm at 43, Moorgate Street; 115 cheques (produced) are all drawn by Perryman to me between November, 1891, and October, 1906. In November. 1906, I was subpœnaed to give evidence in a case. against H.K. Ablett. I saw Perryman about the Court. I told him that I was subpœnaed. I do not recollect what he said, but he mentioned to me that I was not to say that he was H.K. Ablett.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. As I had seen Ablett I should think there was no necessity for anybody to say that Perry
man was not Ablett. I think the photograph (Exhibit 211) is like Herbert Smith, whom I have seen once or twice. In March, 1905, I moved a quantity of account books and old financial newspapers, amounting to about a ton weight, and sold them as waste paper. I may have got cheques from Herbert Smith for work done at 43, Moor
gate Street. The bundle of 115 cheques handed to me contains a number payable to my father and brother, who both worked for Perry
man. I believe Perryman has paid me in respect of work done on Chalmers and Cox circulars—I cannot swear to any circular. I have, often got changed poet-dated cheques for Perryman, which were made payable to me, and handed him the money. He has also on several occasions lent me money by cheque.

LOUISE STRICK , 35, Lisson Grove, widow. I have known Perryman since 1886, and have acted as his private secretary down to about 1902. Harris was Perryman's clerk. Hawkes and Tyler frequently called at the office. From July. 1902, to June, 1905, I lived at Closely Mansions, Cray's Inn Road. I have frequently visited the offices of Herbert Smith, 43, Moorgate Street. I have seen Smith there, and knew him formerly. I have also visited 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, and seen Harris and Perryman there. I told Perryman that I was looking for lodgers, and he asked me if I would take in any letters or parcels for H.K. Ablett. I agreed to do so.
Cross-examined by Sir C. Mathews. I do not remember if it was Harris first mentioned Ablett's name—he was in the office at the
time. This was about 1905 or 1906. I frequently went to the office between 1902 and 1905.
(Wednesday, October 30.)

ERNEST JOHN DORNER , clerk at London City and Midland Bank, Fenchurch Street, identified from a photograph Herbert Smith as a customer of the bank, and produced a copy of his account from the beginning of May. 1902. The account was originally opened in 1882 and continued open until April, 1888, when Herbert Smith became bankrupt, but the bank was not apprised of that fact. The account was opened again in 1889 and continued alive until 1904. Witness also produced a statement of the payments out and payments in.

HENRY ARTHUR SMITH , clerk at the London Trading Bank, Lom
bard Street, produced a copy of the account of Henry King Ablett commencing July 3, 1906, and continuing till May 26, 1906, that being the date of the last operation upon it. The address given by Ablett was Clovelly Mansions, Gray's Inn Road. Witness also pro
duced copies of the payments in and payments out.

ROBERT EDWARD KIELEY , assistant cashier, London and Joint Stock Bank, produced a copy of the account opened on October 5, 1903, in the name of Herbert Smith. (Witness produced the signature book which the prosecution allege was signed by Harris.) Smith described himself as a newspaper proprietor, of 43, Moorgate Street.

(The above three witnesses were cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall as to the proportion of payments out by cheques passing through the Clearing House, to payments out in cash, with a view to show
ing that the account was consistent with the transaction of genuine business.)

MR. KIELEY , re-examined. I have supplied to the defendants figures of payments in showing the notes as distinct from the cheques. I have not been asked by defendants to supply the identification num
bers of notes paid to credit. We have got them in our books.

RICHARD EDWARD CAREY , clerk to Schultz, Comings and Co., char
tered accountants, 50, Cannon Street. Mr. Comins is liquidator of the Economic Bank, and the books are in his possession. (Witness produced copy of the account opened in the name of Henry Keith Ablett, showing total credits £212 10s.) I have the signature book, which shows "H.K. Ablett" as the form of signature. I could not say that the signature "H. Smith" in Exhibit 228a is in the same writing. (Tracing of signatures in the accounts of the London Trad
ing Bank were put to witness.) I should say the signature "H.K. Ablett" here was the same as in our book. (Copy of account of Alex, Robert Fraser was proved by witness, containing a number of pay
ments to "Parkinson, Argus," a great number to Harris, and one to Martin on October 31, £110; on to Long on October 7, £50. (Signature of "A.R. Fraser" in signature book was identified by witness, who said that some lithographed signatures on some cir
culars were apparently the same.) I prepared a portion of the par
ticulars of payments out from the account from the books of the bank, which is correct.

Cross-examined by Mr. Leycester. I cannot say whether the Eco
nomic Bank was a non-clearing bank.

H.A. SMITH , recalled. I have made tracings of the signatures of Chalmers and Cox and of H.K. Ablett (same produced). (Mr. Ley
cester said he did not deny that the writing in the signatures of Ablett and Herbert Smith was that of Harris.)

ROBERT EDWARD KIELEY , recalled, produced certain figures he had taken out in regard to the London Joint Stock Bank, showing £1,506 15s. 1d. paid over counter, £13 6s. 7d. bank's charges, cheques paid through clearing banks £11,519 5s. 7d.

FREDERICK BRADBROOK SEYMOUR , clerk to the Middlesex Banking Company. 89, Leadenhall Street, produced a certified copy from the bank books of the account of George Martin. He identified George Martin as prisoner Harris. The account was opened on April 9, 1906, and last operated on on May 17, 1907. Martin's address was 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. The account showed cheques drawn to Perryman £15 12s. 6d. and £15 10s. on August 31, 1906; also cheques to Bleach in December, 1906. There was a cheque of Mr. Lever £10, April 23, 1906, paid into the account. There was also an account kept at his bank in the name of W. Tyler and Co., Pinner's Hall, opened on October 15, 1906. (Witness produced certified copy of the account, showing numbers of notes, where cheques were cashed over the counter, drawn by W. Tylet and Co., also the details of pay
ments into gold, etc.) The account was last operated on on May 27, 1907, the date on which Tyler was arrested. The balance £33 was taken by the bank for charges. There were a great many cheques drawn on the account which were cashed into notes or gold. Cheques from Mrs. Pittet £15, and Mr. Read £100, were paid into the ac
count on October 24, 1906, and April 16 respectively; also a cheque for £50 drawn by Read on April 22. Defendant Tyler was the per
son who had that account.
To Mr. Marshall Hall. I do not know Perryman.

Cross-examined by Mr. F.E. Smith. No one operated on the ac
count except Tyler. Ours is a non-clearing bank. The cheque for £100 on April 16 would take about two days to clear, the £50 one, was a country cheque; it would take about three days.

HENRY LISTER BASS , clerk to London City and Midland Bank, Queen Victoria Street, produced certified copy of account of Perryman, beginning May 1, 1902, down to June 30, 1907, and giving numbers of notes where credits were in notes, also particulars where credits were in coin. There was also another account for a short time.
Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. I could not tell you how long the account has been opened; this is only an extract; I believe it has been opened a good many years.
To Mr. F.E. Smith. I did not know Tyler.

Miss
LUCIA SOPHIA GRITTITHS , White House, East Thorpe, Kelve
don, Essex. In January this year I got a circular like the one pro
duced, which I read through, and believed the statements therein. I sent £5 in response, I think. I received letter (produced) from Wil
liam

Tyler and Co., acknowledging £5 as deposit on the purchase of five Rio Tin to shares, and enclosing contract for same. The con
tract was: "We sell you on our usual terms five Rio Tin to shares at 93 1/4. I received the letter of February 5 from William Tyler and Co., saying that owing to a set-back in the market yesterday the cover became exhausted, and that it would be necessary to send another £5 to make 2 per cent, cover, etc. I next had a letter saying they had had no reply from me, and presuming I did not wish to continue the shares, enclosing contract. I replied, saying that I did not feel I could risk another £5, etc. I then received another letter from them advising me to send further money for the purpose of a fresh speculation. I sent them £10 more, which they acknowledged as being £5 on 2 percent, cover on purchase of Brighton "A's," and £5 deposit on Rio Tintos, also sending contracts at the day's prices. On February 21 I received another letter saying that, regarding Brighton "As my cover had been exhausted, and presuming I wished to continue had debited the Rio Tinto's, which had risen, with the £5 necessary to continue. I am not sure what I replied to that, but I got a further letter as follows: "With regard to Rio Tintos which you have opened, we shall be glad if you will let us know whether you will leave the closing in our hands. If you decide to leave it to us you might rely upon us doing he best for you in the matter." My answer was: "I will leave the closing in your hands; hoping you will do full justice to me. You do not mention the Brighton 'A.' Is it quite gone?" Further correspondence took place, in the course of which they asked for £4 7s. 6d. in order to keep my interest going. I replied, "I am unable to forward another sum of £4 7s. 6d. at pre
sent. Would it be possible therefore to retain the Rio Tintos even if I forego the Brighton 'A,' or must I close up both accounts?" The account (produced) I received from Tyler and Co., showing a balance in my favour of 12s. 6d. I had not heard about contango before that account; I do not know what it arena. They wrote me again saying that unless I was prepared to pay the difference due they would have to close; and I wrote telling them to do so. They acknowledged, and said they had closed my account; afterwards send
ing me their account, giving the purchases and prices, and showing amount necessary to balance £41 5s. I sent them £3 as instalment, saying I would send another £9 in a few days. On March 25 I had another letter from them asking for a further remittance as they had a heavy account to deal with. The acknowledgments (produced) are from Tyler and Co. for £3 15s., for 30s., March 28. and £20 on April 9, making the amount paid up £25 5s. I think that was the last I sent I got another letter on May 29 asking for more, but that is all I could manage. Some little time later I saw something in the news
papers, and did not think it wise to send more. I remember getting a circular (produced) from the "Financial Guardian" last year, in consequence of which I sent £5 deposit on the purchase of five Rio Tintos, which was acknowledged the letter (produced). I never got anything back from the "Financial Guardian." When I got the

circulars from William Tyler and Co. I had not any knowledge of what they were, but I thought it was a proper place; that they would do what they professed to do. I had no idea they were connected with the "Financial Guardian."

Cross-examined by Mr. F.E. Smith. I had had no other expe
rience on the Stock Exchange. I read the whole of the circular of October 13 through, and I thought I was actually buying the shares I thought I was getting the value of them for my £5, and thought I was buying five shares at a value of about 98; but I suppose I was making a mistake. I did not ask at any time what the actual value was. I thought I understood the circular, but evidently I did not. It said something about the shares rising and failing. I knew when I sent the money that my liability was to be limited to the £1 per share deposit. I think I pencilled notes of my replies to letters, without actually keeping copies. (Mr. F.E. Smith put several letters to wit
ness with a view to showing that she was wrong in her dates, and varied her notes in the actual letters sent.) I was willing that the loss on the Brighton "A" should be covered by the rise in the Tintos. When Tyler and Co. asked me to leave the matter to their discretion I suppose I understood that I was taking the chance of whether the shares rose or fell. I was willing at that time to leave it to their dis
cretion, and to go beyond the original risk—I believe so. I knew that if I had not varied the original arrangement there would have been no more money due.

Mrs.
JULIA HENRIETTA PITTET , Frederica Road, Chingford, widow, said she had received a circular on October 24 from William Tyler and Co. She had never bought any stocks or shares before, but on reading the circular, which she thought she understood, she deter
mined to send some money for some Rio Tinto shares, and sent cheque for £15. Later on witness received a letter (October 29) ad
visinga her to increase her interest as the shares were almost sure to improve, etc., but she did not send any more money. A further cir
cular was sent her, dated November 7, in which the United States Steel Corporation was mentioned, and setting forth the great advan
tages of securing an interest therein. Witness read this through, but told them they must settle the account for the Rio Tintos before she sent more money. She wrote on January 7 this year requesting a settlement, but got nothing. In consequence of what witness saw in the newspapers she wrote closing the stock, but got no answer. About a fortnight later she wrote again, having obtained advice, and told them they (Tyler and Co.) were only a bucket shop and did no business. No reply was obtained. I had no other communication with Tyler and Co. I have had back no part of my £15. I con
sulted a friend, a Mr. Thomas Clay, with reference to this matter.

Cross-examined by Mr. F.E. Smith. I had had no previous deal
ings in stocks. Some shares have been taken for me by friends. I knew of the transactions, but I understand, being a foreigner, that shares are a different thing from stock. I have had dealings in Industrial shares. When I was in Croydon I took shares in a com
pany,

Williams and Wilcocks. I have not indulged in a little specu
lation from time to time. I did invest in Meters, Limited. That is what you rail Industrial shares. I arranged that for myself. I knew by this time how to do it. When I first started I did not know Williams and Wilcocks was earlier in date than my investment with Tyler. What I mean is that I do not understand about stock on the Stock Exchange; shares are a very different thing. When I received the circulars from Tylers I did not know it was a "bucket" shop, or I should not have sent the money. With shares I know you get your dividend quarterly or half yearly, or yearly, but with the Exchange it is a very different matter, and I understand that dealing with a "bucket" shop is a very risky thing. I knew that on the Stock Ex
change you get your money very soon, but I do not think I knew that if I dealt with a firm that was not on the Stock Exchange that was a "bucket" shop. When I entered into this deal with Tyler I did not think I was making an investment in Industrial shares. I knew it was a speculation in differences. I looked at the prospectus, which tells you it is perfectly safe and you never lose anything.

Mr. F.E. Smith. But, you remember, the statement about not losing anything is qualified by the words, "should the quotation re
main the same." You took it with a grain of salt, did not you, with your experience.

Witness. I knew I should not keep the holding long. I know, of course, that £1 would not buy a £97 share, and I knew I was having, a deal in differences which might turn out well or might turn out badly; at the same time, I saw on the papers it was very likely to be a good thing. I thought from the prospectus it would turn out well. I would not, of course, have given any money for nothing. Assuming that I would be paid. I was perfectly prepared to have a gamble. I suppose that would be the object everybody bets on the Stock Exchange. I did not think I was only gambling in differences be
cause I was to have a dividend on my money as well. I supposed that stock dealers would have the stock if they wanted to sell it. If they were going to pay a dividend they must have it. I understood from the circular that "should the quotation remain the same". I should make this profit, and that if, on the other hand, the quotation fell I was exposed to risk. As to whether I understood the prin
ciple on which this speculation was based, I understood that as soon as the dividend was paid I would claim it, and I knew it was only a few days before I could claim it. I expected Tylers to settle when it would be paid; they did not do anything at all.

Re examined. I considered I was entitled to the dividend and to the additional profit of the rise on the strength of the following pas
sage in the circular: "Investors will see that by buying at once they are making an absolute certainty, should the quotation remain the same, to receive a dividend two and a half times as much as their deposit. More than the amount of the dividend will in all pro
bability be gained by an investment now, for every advance in the quotation makes a further profit for the buyer, who is at the same
time protected from any loss or liability over the original deposit of £1 per share." I wrote to close the transaction when a profit was shown and could get no answer.

THOMAS EDWARD HENRY CLAY , Bank House, Chingford. The last witness spoke to me about Tyler and Co., and in the beginning of 1907 I called on them at Pinner's Hall a good many times. Twice when I went there was somebody there; at other times the place was locked. I usually went about half past five. Afterwards went between two and three, and found a young lady, whom I took to be a typist. I tried several times to find Tyler. There was no sign of business, no books, or papers. I afterwards wrote to him about Mrs. Pittet's business, and received a reply, dated February 25, to the effect that the matter would be looked into. I wrote again on March 4 and got this answer. "We are in receipt of your favour of yesterday's date, and in reply beg to say we have looked into Mrs. Pittet's account and find we had 15 Rio Tinto shares open for her, which were closed last November as per instructions, when they were quoted ex div. We also note that we have not settled with her, but apparently the matter has been overlooked. We will make up the account and forward it to her next pay day." That was the last I heard from Wm. Tyler and Co.
Cross-examined by Mr. F.E. Smith: I never went into the inner office. I did not go beyond the counter. I have an idea there was a copying press Share.

EDITH M.T. BUTCHER . I live at the Chestnuts, Footstone, with my husband. I received a circular, dated February 14, 1906, headed "Canadian Pacific Bonus," and dealing with an issue of Canadian Pacific shares. Believing the statements in the circular, I filled in an application form, enclosed a cheque for £150, being at the rate of 3 per cent, on £5,000 nominal stock, and sent it to the "Financial Guardian." The circular was signed "H.K. Alblett," and in due course I received a contract note. Correspondence followed. I was under the impression that after the stock was ex div. my account was still in credit. On April 26 I went to Tokenhouse Buildings, where I saw a person I now recognise as the prisoner Harris. I asked, if Mr. Ablett was in. He said "No, he is out of town." I asked when he would be in, and Harris replied that ha would be back on Monday, it being then Thursday. I said I did not know whether I should call again, and I came away. I gave him my name. I do not recollect that he asked any other question. The same day I consulted my solicitor, Mr. Hall. I never got back any part of the £150. A writ was issued, but Mr. Ablett was said to be in Paris, and Mr. Hall did not think it worth while to continue the action.

Cross-examined by Mr. Leycester. I had had no experience of Stock Exchange transactions. I have never invested money. I know that when people invest money they get certificates for their shares or bonds. I understood these shares ware held on the cover system, 3 per cent cover being deposited. If the shares had dropped in value more than 3 per cent. I should, of course, have lost my money.

but they did not drop. As to the bonus, I suppose these people had information. I did not know whether it was secret or not. I thought I was to have the bonus. I thought on the circular I was entitled to it. I thought I was to have both the dividend and the bonus. I never considered whether those payments would affect the price of the shares. I did not at the time know when the dividend was due, but I thought it would be paid soon. The circular is very misleading. I thought the bonus was a thing that was paid every year. As to whether I thought there was a possibility of my losing my money, I am afraid I did not understand very much about it then.
(Thursday, October 31.)

PERCY HEDLEY HALL . Examined by Mr. Bodkin. I am a solicitor, a member of the firm of Cooper, Walker, and Hall, 7, Birchin Line. Towards the end of April. 1906, I was consulted by Mrs. Butcher in reference to the "Financial Guardian," and on her instructions wrote a letter to Ablett (Exhibit 73). The next day I got Exhibit 74 in reply. I wrote another letter, stating that the cover had pot run of as they had said. Before writing that letter I had carefully looked through the official list with regard to Canadian Pacific stock. In answer to that I got Exhibit 76. I wrote another letter offering to take up the stock less the amounts paid or take £150 in settlement I got no reply and commenced an action against Ablett, claiming the return of £150, or, in the alternative, £150 damages for breach of contract. I was not able to effect service, and an order was made for substituted service, and I sent a writ with a copy of the order by post to Ablett. In reply I got a letter signed "George Martin," initialed "J.R.," stating Ablett had nothing to do with the business and had gone abroad without leaving his address. (Exhibit 81.) The documents were returned. After that I advised my client not to waste any more money over it, and the action was abandoned alto
gether. I have not received any part of the £150.

Cross-examined by Mr. Wellesley Orr. When Mrs. Butcher con
sulted me she brought me a circular. I saw it was the usual cover transaction. I think my information that the cover had not run off came from the daily paper. I know the daily paper only gives the closing quotations. A different price might have ruled in the middle of the day. I did not take in the "Financial News" and I did not have a tape, and consequently I looked at the "Daily Telegraph" to verify what Mrs. Butcher told me. I called at Abletts office twice and found the typewriter girl there. I could get nothing out of her, and. therefore, I wrote. The second time I called she said, "It will be all right; Mr. Ablett will attend to it." She did not seem to understand much about it and treated me in an offhand way. The claim for "breach of contract" was a formal thing. In issuing Mayor's Court summonses we have to comply with the usual regula
tions.

FREDERICK REED , Elmcroft, Bedfont, no occupation. In April this year I received circulars 16 and 17 from W. Tyler and Co., pointing out the advantages of buying at once shares in Rio Tinto. I deter
mined to buy 100 shares and sent a cheque for £100 to Tyler and Co., filling up the yellow application form as directed. That cheque has been paid by my bankers. In reply I got letter No. 18, and a volume giving the history of the Rio Tinto Mine. I also got the contract for the sale of the 100 shares. (Exhibit 19.) I was an invalid and did not read the terms of business on the back. I posted the letter, enclosing the cheque, before the last post for London, which goes out between seven and eight. I had crossed the cheque. I got a letter from Tyler and Co., dated April 18 (Exhibit 21), and determined to buy 400 more Rio Tinto shares. On April 20 I for
warded two cheques to W. Tyler and Co., one for. £50, which I crossed, and another for £350, which was uncrossed. Both have been paid by my bankers. I got back Exhibit 23, dated April 22, and on the 24th or 25th I got Exhibit 24, which is dated April 24, which latter refers to the fact that my letter enclosing the two cheques did not reach them till the Monday morning. I received a contract for the Rio Tinto shares, dated April 23, selling to me 400 Rio Tintos at 92 3/4 cum. dividend for the end April account. On the back there are some conditions printed, but I did not read them. It is very unusual for any contract note sent by a broker to bear any conditions at all. I watched the quotations in the financial papers and then wrote to Tyler and Co. I said I considered Rio Tintos were rising up to the time that the dividend was payable. I noticed that from the tape quotations. I received Exhibit 28, stating the cover had run off on the 24th. I received no other letters from Tyler and Co. I came up to London on April 29 with the intention of going to Tyler and Co.'s, but went somewhere else, and, in consequence of what I heard there, instead of going to Tyler's I went to my soli
citor's and afterwards to the Guildhall Police Court. At the time I received their circular I believed Tyler and Co. to be dealers in Stock Exchange securities, but not that they were members of the Stock Exchange. In parting with my money I understood I was giving £1 cover for every £100 of stock, and that would cover the number of shares I purchased from Tyler, and that the control of those shares would give me the right to the dividend that was approaching quickly. I was going to Tyler and Co. with reference to the pay
ment of those dividends.

Cross-examined by Mr. F. E. Smith. I did not consider I was running any risk. I thought the real question was the payment of the £3 dividend on the 30th. I thought I was certain to get the dividend and make more than I had invested. After the payment of the dividend I thought the shares would rise to their original value. The dividend did not come from Tyler and Co., but from the com
pany. It was no speculation because the dividend had already been declared. I did not contemplate the shares falling more than the £3 a share, which was the dividend. I should only have drawn for

the £3 dividend, and then if I wanted to carry it on to another ac
count I should have arranged to pay the contango. If I did not like to pay the contango I should have sold, and if the shares had fallen 10 points I should have lost. I understood that if the quotation fell I point Tyler and Co. could close the contract unless I deposited fresh cover, but I was entitled to have their advice on the point. Except as regards the dividend, if the market fell, subject to the question of advice, I should not have a grievance against them. I thought I was buying the shares and not making a bet on "differ
ences," because I was working for the dividend. I did not read the "terms of business" on the back of the contract. I was an invalid and did not take the trouble to read them. I considered I was buying the shares or else how could I obtain the dividend? Unless those shares were bought no dividend could have existed. Contracts are read on the face of the contracts. If I had read term 3, "It is fully understood that the stock or shares represented by this contract will sot be taken up or paid for by either party," I should still have thought I was buying the shares because the original circular sent me was the guiding thing. Possibly, if I had read term 5 I should have known what Tyler and Co. were claiming to have the right to do under the contract. I received a letter from them on April 25 stating my cover had become exhausted. I did not consider that if the cover was exhausted the dividend was lost, too. The market had risen. On one letter of theirs I wrote in red ink, "Returned, as the contents are untrue." I meant it was untrue that the quotation had fallen. I cannot say from memory on what days their statements were false as to the quotation. I followed the course of the market in the shares each day with exact care.

Re-examined. "An absolutely secured and certain dividend" is in large type on the circular, and I understood it was so. There are also the words, "There is no liability at all above the amount of deposit, and there is no question but that the above dividend will be paid. This dividend is not a speculation." That is in large type, and that is what I understood. I saw the words in large type, "Our clients' interests and our own are identical," and thought they were probably a very good firm. The circular says, "We advise our clients as to the exact position of the market and what they should do in order to retain their previous interest," and thought it very likely they would send me a letter to that effect.

JOSEPH SEARLE , cashier at the London Joint Stock Bank, Pall Mall. Exhibit 22, a cheque by Mr. Reed for £350 was cashed by me on April 24 across the counter into six £50 notes and £50 in gold. The numbers of the notes were 97427 to 97432. I think it was cashed a few minutes part one. A man named Harris brought it to the bank to be cashed. I recognised him in King's Arms Yard, the Old Jewry Police Office, and told Inspector Ottaway that he was the man. I afterwards recognised him in the police court. The cheque being for a large amount I asked him what the payees were, and he said they were brokers. I asked him if he was one of the firm, and he said
be was simply a clerk. The cheque was properly endorsed and all in order, and I could not refuse to pay it.

Cross-examined by Mr. F. E. Smith. I do not know the time the cheque for £100, dated April 19, was presented. The Middlesex Banking Company, through whom it was paid, is not a clearing house bank; it would come through the Metropolitan Bank. It was drawn on the 15th and paid on the 17th. Probably it would have got to the Middlesex (Bank on the 16th and be presented by them to the London Joint Stock Bank on the 17th. The proceeds would get back to the Middlesex Bank on the same day, the 17th. Assuming the cheque got to us about 12 o'clock, it might have got to the Middlesex Bank directly after they received it if it came by post. They would pay it into the Middlesex Bank at 10 or 11 o'clock. With regard to all the Middlesex Bank cheques which are held by the Metropolitan, directly they are cleared in the hands of the Metropolitan the Metro
politan would communicate to the Middlesex that their balance is so and so. At the close of business on the 17th they would know every
thing was paid.
Cross-examined by Mr. W. Wellesley Orr. When Harris said they were "brokers" I gather he meant stockbrokers. I am sure he said he was a clerk and that he was not a partner in the firm.

JOSEPH PERCIVAL HUDSON , clerk in the Bank Note Department of the Bank of England. I produce six £50 bank notes, 97427 to 97432. No. 97431 bears the stamp of the Finsbury Pavement Post Office. On the back of Nos. 97428-9-30 there is the endorsement "W. Tyler, 54, Old Broad Street, E. C." These notes were cashed at the Bank of England into gold, 97,428 on April 24 and 97,429-30 on April 26. The handwriting of the three endorsements is, in my judgment, the same. No. 97432, endorsed "W. Tyler," was cashed into gold on April 25. The handwriting is different. When a note is cashed into gold at the Bank of England it is usual to ask the person to endorse it, or one of a series cashed at the same time.

EDWARD JONES TRUSTRAM , solicitor, 61, Cheapside. Mr. Reed con
sulted me on April 30 this year year, and in consequence of what he said I made several visits to Tyler's office, Pinner's Hall, on April 30, May 2, May 3, and May 10. I went three times on April 30. The first time the office was shut up with a note pinned on the door, "Back at 2.15." I went and had lunch and went back again and saw Miss Louis. I waited some time and then came back again later in the afternoon. I asked to see Tyler, and the reply was that he might come in at any minute or he might not be there again that day; it was very uncertain. I told the lady what I had called about and wrote my name down for her and what I wanted, and showed her the letters. On May 2 I called about 10.25 am. I tried the door and it was locked. I made a noise on the outside but did not get any answer, so I left. On May 3 and May 10 the same thing occurred. I was never able to see Tyler. I represented the prose
cution at the very commencement as solicitor for Mr. Reed. I got possession from Inspector Ottaway of a press letter copybook of W.

Tyler and Co, of the dates January lo April, 1907, and went through it page by page, and found what purported to be press copies of a number of selling and closing contracts. In the opening contracts the prices are not filled in at the same time as the typewritten form is filled up. For the most part they are filled in in ink. The closing contracts appear to be filled in by the typist on the machine all at the same time. The press copy of the opening contracts is typewritten in typewriting copying ink, but the prices at which Tyler's sell are filled in in ink or coloured pencil, with about six exceptions. There were 63 contracts. In five the price was blank; six appeared to have been filled up at the same time; 46 were filled up in ink after
wards; and in six the type is altered or it is typed in at a different time, as it appears to me. With regard to the closing contracts, there are about three or four cases where the price was not filled in at the same time, out of about 60.

Cross-examined by Mr. F. E. Smith. I went six times to Tyler's office. The longest time I stayed was 20 minutes, when I was talk
ing to Miss Latus about the £500 my client had lost. I went there at 10.25 on all three days, and at 2.50 and 3.45 as well on the first day. The closing contracts are filled in in type. I did not advertise for persons who wished to bring claims against Tyler.

JOHN THOMAS LEVER , surveyor, Witham, Essex. About February 20 last year I received a circular (Exhibit 82) signed George Martin, purporting to be from the "Financial Guardian, Share Department," of which George Martin was the manage. It recommends the pur
chase of Canadian Pacific shares and states that the purchase of the shares would carry a bonus of about £16 a share. I wrote letter 83, and afterwards letter 84, with a cheque for £30 to George Martin, which was endorsed "George Martin" and paid by my bank. I got Exhibits 85 and 86, the contract showing "£1,000 Canadian Pacific stock at 175 1/2 cum bonus. (Signed) George Martin. Cover deposit £30, 3 per cent. Cash received." And then there is added, "With limited liability." Account No. 88 it headed, "Account end of March. J. T. Lever in account with George Martin," and shows that I, holding £1,755 value of fifty Canadian Pacifies, and charged con
tango on that amount at 5 per cent, per annum for 13 days, coming to £3 2s. 6d. Exhibit 89 is the cheque I paid that account with. I received Exhibit 90 and afterwards called at 2, Tokenhouse Build
ings and asked for Mr. Martin. Harris came forward and said, "He is not here." He did not think he would be in all day. I said I had come purposely to see him and wanted to settle my account. He said. "He is in Manchester; you cannot see him." He promised me a settlement for next settling day. Canadian Pacific stock was higher than that at which I purchased it. From the first moment I had bought it it had not gone down at all; it had gone up. When I said I wanted to settle my account I meant I wanted to close it I said there and then, "Harris, I would like to close at once. I would like to close the stock at once," or something of that sort. I believe I said, "The stock shows a good

profit; it is well up; close it at once." He agreed to close. I saw a couple of girls also in the office. I do not think they were doing anything. One of them was rather a rude young lady—the one exa
mined here the other day. It was early in the morning I paid my visit. I went back to Witham, and next morning received letter 91 signed "George Martin" dated April 19, 1906. Contract 92 was en
closed, showing that the "Financial Guardian" Share Department bought from me under-noted shares to close Canadian Pacific £1,000 stock 177 7/8 cum. bonus, I having bought at 175 1/2. I got no cheque or remittance. I then wrote 93 and got answer 94. Letter 93 pointed out that the papers said 183 1/2. I got my price from the "Daily Telegraph." On April 21 I got a circular from the "Finan
cial Guardian" about Rio Tintos. I sent cheque No. 96 for £10 for 10 Rio Tintos, which was paid by my bank. I got an acknowledg
ment and a contract for the shares at 65 7/8. I had had nothing on ac
count of Canadian Pacific's and wrote letter 99, and got letter 100. The next pay day would be somewhere about May 12. I went up to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings and asked for Martin, and Harris said he was not in town. I told him I wanted a settlement of my account. Harris said I might expect a settlement for certain the next pay day. He said they had been hit very hard and had lost about £2,000 and same of their clients were pressing them hardly. I waited till July 6, when I wrote letter 101, to which I got no reply. I waited again a long time and then called at the office, about three times altogether, and saw Harris. He said something to the same effect as before. Then I wrote letter 102 on October 27, and, not getting any reply; I gave my solicitor instructions in the matter. I never had any part of the money.
