My solicitor took proceedings on my behalf. When I parted with my money, having read she circular, I thought the "Financial Guardian" was a paper; I did not know they were bucket-shop people. From first to last I was not able to see Mr. George Martin.

Crocs-examined by Mr. Wellesley Orr. I did not understand this was a speculation or a cover transaction. I did not expect to get the scrip, but I would much rather have taken up the shares than lose too money. I was prepared to find the value of the shares. I dis
puted the price at the time of closing the shares, but I was claiming the difference shown upon the contracts. The amount of the profit was put down at £118 15s. That was done by my solicitors. I was not angry when I did not get any satisfactory reply in April, but I could not think they were treating me fairly. I was a double fool to invest with them again. I did not know whether Rio Tintos have gone steadily up or not. It was a bad investment for me. I have not got the money. If they had given me £40 I would have been de
lighted, but they would not pay anything, and they never have paid anything.
FREDERICK LEWIS , managing clerk to W. B. Glasier, Essex Street, Strand, solicitor. On instructions of Livesey I issued writ against George Martin, "Financial Guardian," 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, to

recover £148 15s., being £118 15s. profit upon 50 Canadian Pacific shares and £30 amount paid as deposit. An appearance was entered Minton, Slater, and Co., for the defendant, and an affidavit (pro
duced) of George Martin, denying liability, was filed. The claim was based upon contract notes of the defendant, showing that the 50 shares were bought at 175 1/2 and sold at 177 7/8, being £2 7s. 6d. profit on each of the 50 shares—£118 15s., together with £30 deposit. The action was put in the Short Cause List before Sutton, J. Counsel appeared for defendant, and we obtained judgment, with costs, amounting to about £44. We got no money, and within a fortnight of the judgment the defendants were arrested. Notice of appeal was given, but was never entered.
Cross-examined by Mr. Orr. The plaintiff did not state that the transaction was a gaming one.

ALICE RUDOLPHINE D'ALTERA , 12, Waverley Road, Folkestone. In December, 1905, I received circular (produced) from Financial Guardian and Mining Market Mirror, Share Department, offering Golden Rhodesians. I did not purchase. I afterwards got circular (produced) signed "H. K. Ablett," offering Canadian Pacific shares, and on February 16,1906, I sent cheque (produced) for £30, which is endorsed by "H. K. Ablett," and has been honoured. I received con
tract note showing that 50 shares had been purchased for me at 176 5/8. On March 1 I received letter (produced), and on March 2 sent another £30 as further cover. I afterwards sent a bundle of cheques (produced) for small amounts for contango amounting to £61 in response to fortnightly accounts (produced), signed "H. K. Ablett." I wrote for the money several times, and on March 4, 1907, I received letter (produced) from George Martin, stating that Mr. H. K. Ablett had been away some time, and he would try to get into communica
tion with him. On March 25 I received letter and account (pro
duced) showing a debit balance against me of £21 0s. 3d. The ac
count shows a charge for 167 days contango from October 11 to March 27 amounting to £54 15s. 3d. I replied, and on March 27 I received a letter signed by "H. K. Ablett," stating that I had been credited with bonus to the extent of £110, and the account would be made up later. I received nothing from the "Financial Guardian." I thought it was a genuine firm.

Cross-examined by Mr. Wellesley Orr. I believed that I was buying the shares with the £30, and that according to the circular "there was no further liability." I sent the second £30 because I thought it was needed to keep them going. I did not know the market price of the shares. I do not know what "taking up a share" means. I did not write that I had already bought the shares and there was nothing more to pay. I have not taken legal proceed
ings. I intended to do so, and I believe I said so in the last letter I wrote.

WILLIAM THOMAS MOORE , clerk, Filing Department, Royal Courts of Justice. I produce affidavit of George Harris, sworn for the de
fendant on August 9, 1904, in Leslie v. Smith; affidavit of George

Harris, August 9, in Ashworth v. Smith; affidavit of George Martin of October 13, 1906, in Beet v. "Financial Guardian"; affidavit of George Martin in Innes v. "Financial Guardian," filed October 30, 1906; affidavit of George Martin of November 24, 1906, in Mellhuish v. "Financial Guardian."

Detective-inspector
JOHN PTTAWAY , City, On May 9, 1907, I kept observation on 16, Great St. Helen's, saw Tyler leave, and followed him to W. Tyler and Co.'s office, Pinner's Hall. I went in and saw Claire Latus in the outer office, the door to the inner room being open, I said, "I have called on behalf of Madame Pittet, of Chingford. I want to see one of the principals." She said, "Mr. Tyler is not in." I said, "Can you tell me when he will be in?" She said, "No, he it in and out all day. Madame Pittet had better write." I said, "Madam Pittet is tired of writing, that is the reason I called. I will come back later." I kept observation on the office, and two or three minutes later Tyler came out. On May 27 I received warrant for Tyler's arrest, saw him in Tokenhouse Yard, and told him I held a warrant for his arrest for obtaining money by false pretences. I took him to the Chief Office of Police and read the warrant, which related to £15 obtained from Madame Pittet. He said, "They can charge me if they like, but I do not think they can do it." A little later he said, "I know nothing about the business, although I am nominally responsible." I then searched the office at Pinners Hall; Latus and Reece were there. In the outer office were two fixed desks, a stool, a copying press, two packets of headed notepaper, 92 prints of the Rio Tinto mine, a bundle of folded circulars (produced), many hundreds of addressed envelopes, and several lists of investors. There were no books of account whatever. I then went to the office of Gibbs and Tyler, 16, Great St. Helen's. The names up were "Malayian Property Syndicate" and "Malayian Para Rubber Estates, Limited"—not the name of "Gibbs and Tyler." I found a number of cheque books, mostly used, on the Middlesex Bank, signed "William Tyler and Co."; memorandum book containing pay
ments in and out to "George." Pass book of W. Tyler and Co. with the London and Provincial Bank. In the memorandum book was written "7348 Wall," which is the telephone number of the "Financial Guardian." I also found circulars and notepaper of W. Tyler and Co.; press copy letter book of Gibbs and Tyler; cheque for £86 14s. 6d. by W. Tyler and Co. to Perryman. (The witness gave evidence as to the handwriting on a number of cheques.) I then returned to the police-station and saw Tyler. I said, "I have searched your office, but I have failed to find any books of account. I want you to tell me where they are." He said, "If you go to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings and see George Harris he may give you some." I asked for a letter of authority, which he gave me, as follows: "Dear George,—I have been arrested and am going to Moor Lane, Detective Ottaway is coming up to see you."

To Mr. F. E. Smith. I cannot say whether I cautioned Tyler be
fore this—I certainly cautioned him afterwards.

To Mr. Orr. I cautioned Harris after he had pretended to make a search at the office for the books. I went to 2, Tokenhouse Build
ings and said to Harris. "Tyler is in custody; he has been arrested upon a charge of obtaining money by false pretences in connection with the business at Pinner's Hall. I understand that you. have some books belonging to him here." I then produced Tyler's letter. Harris said, "I do not think that there are any here." He then went into the private office, came out almost immediately, and looked in a cup
board, and said, "There does not appear to be any here." I said, 'I am not satisfied with the way in which you have searched, you have books here, and I want them before I leave." He them went to the cupboard and produced letter book of Tyler and Co. I said, "How is it that you have got Tyler and Co.'s letter book here." He said, "Tyler brought it up to ask a question on a point of law" I said, "Who is the tenant of these offices?" Harris said, "I do not know, but I think George Martin." He brought four press copy letter books of the "Financial Guardian "out of the cupboard. I knew him as Harris. I then returned to the police office with Tyler's letter book and told Tyler that this was the only book I had obtained from Harris and that I did not recognise the writing a a his or his lady clerk's. I asked him whose writing it was. He said, "I do not know." I said, "It is strange you do not know whose writing this is if this is your business."

To Mr. F. E. Smith. I now recollect that I cautioned Tyler be
fore I went to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings.

To Mr. Bodkin. On May 28 Tyler was brought up before the Alder
man, the hearing was adjourned, and by June 11 I received warrant for the arrest of Harris. I found a number of documents at Tyler's house, including those from Smiles. On June 11 I arrested Harris in Lothbury.
To Mr. Orr. I cautioned Harris at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, when I made inquiries as to the books of Tyler and Co. I did so because I was satisfied he was not speaking the truth.

To Mr. Bodkin. I read the warrant to him. He said, "You have made a great mistake." Later I told him he had been identified as the person who cashed a cheque for £350 on April 24 on the London Joint Stock Bank, Pall Mall, which had been sent to Tyler and Co. He said, "Tyler asked me to cash the cheque, and I afterwards paid him the money." I then went to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings and found a number of books, papers relating to William Tyler and Co., Herbert Smith, Chalmers and Cox, and the "Financial Guardian," and to another bucket shop, "A. M. Noble." On the door was painted "Rand Roodeport Mining Company" and "Gold Coast Property Owners, Limited," and on a piece of paper stuck up at the side of the door was written, "The Financial Guardian and Mining Market Mirror." On the same landing was a room with "C. W. P." on the door, of which the key was in the other office. I found it empty except for a rolled top desk which belonged to the landlord; the place was covered with dust and apparently unused; there were no books.

In the offices I found no account books of any kind—only letter books. I also went to an address given by Harris as his private address at 179, Dames Road, Forest Gate. I there found a postcard and a letter signed "Mabel," which I showed to Harris and said, "I understand these are from a young lady typist of yours?" He said, "Yes—Miss Long." I found writing of Long's in the letter books and Tyler and Co., of the Lombard Financial Corporation and of Herbert Smith. In Tyler and Company's books it is her and Harris's writing only.
(Friday, November 1.)

JOHN OTTAWAY , recalled. On June 27 I had a warrant for the arrest of Perryman. I saw him in Old Jewry, and asked him to go to the police-office there. I read the warrant, which charged him with conspiring with Tyler and Harris to obtain money and valuable securities by false pretences. He said, "Who had the temerity to lay this information." I said "Upon my information the warrant was granted." He said, "A police officer is not a very substantial person to obtain redress from." I searched 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, and found three letter-books containing letters signed by Perryman, letter-books of the "Financial Observer," a bundle of cheques, and files of the "Mining Market Mirror and Mining Herald." Perryman had no other down to June, 1907. I found cheques on his account at the London City and Midland Bank in favour of Bleach; to George Harris, endorsed by Harris; to George Martin, in the handwriting of Perryman; to C. George, endorsed by Harris, and in his handwriting; one cheque drawn to Barnes; a number of cheques payable to Herbert Smith and H. Smith, endorsed in Harris's writing; one to H. Smith, endorsed by Perryman. I found the cheques all together. There were a number of counterfoil paying-in slips in the handwriting of Mabel Long and Harris. The body of some of the cheque is in Mabel Long's handwriting. I also found cheques payable to Hawkes, some endorsed by him and others by Harris; also letter-books of Herbert Smith, containing letters written from 43, Moorgate Street, and 27, Sun Street, many in Perryman's handwriting, and containing a great many accounts in Perryman's handwriting; one letter-book commencing with Herbert Smith, at page 270, is continued in the name of H. K. Ablett, signed by Harris. I found a large number of circulars in the name of William Tyler and Co., H. K. Ablett, G. Martin, Chalmers and Cox, A. M. Noble, and Lombard Financial Corporation (signed by a stamp in the name of A. R. Fraser). I found letter from Mrs. Butcher, addressed to Ablett; green paper memorandum list of customers in Perryman's writing, showing that they had been dealt with by Martin or Ablett, including the name of Mrs. d'Alters, dealt with by Ablett, and Mullins, dealt with by "G. M." (Martin); paying-in book of George Martin with Middlesex Bank, in Harris's writing. Some of the circulars are altered in Perryman's writing. In one of H. Smith's letter-books 30 consecutive pages are in Perryman's writing. There

were also a bundle of receipts to C. W. Perryman, lists of country investors in the Aerated Bread Company and others, invoice of Dalby, Walsh and Co. for supplying same. Rubber stamps "George Martin," "Herbert Smith," "The Rand Roodeport Gold Mining Co.," etc. The signature of "Alexander R. Fraser" in the signature-book of the Economic Bank and upon the circulars is Mabel Long's handwriting.

Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. I did not search 2, Token-house Buildings after the arrest of Perryman. I have produced all the documents which I think important in this case. At Pinner's Hall I found nothing belonging to Perryman except the furniture. I found on Perryman some cards of 41, Charing Cross Road. He said it was an old address; that he used to live there. I did not search 41, Charing Cross Road, nor did I find any documents relating to it. Excepting in Harris's office I found nothing at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings; there was nothing in the room marked "C. W. P." I found 42 cheque books containing several thousands of cheques. I have only produced one cheque filled up by Mabel Long, dated Oc
tober 8, 1906, to Allen for £65, and another to Nixon and Arnold of June 18. There may be others. I have only seen postcard and letter of Mabel Long's admitted handwriting. I have been told she is in Calcutta. I did not find at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings thousands of circulars from outside brokers—I found a very few from persons unconnected with the prisoner's businesses; there were, perhaps, half a dozen from Martin, Bull and Co., and Mackenzie. (Witness admitted the payment of several sums to customers, referring to the accounts in Perryman's handwriting.)

Cross-examined by Mr. F. E. Smith. When I called on May 9 at Tyler's office I was not asked my name by Miss Latus. When arrested Tyler did not say, "I am responsible"; he said, "I am nominally responsible." I cautioned him when I was asking him with regard to the account books as to where they were. When I arrested Tyler I found certain testimonials and certificates of character at his ad
dress in Great St. Helens. I took possession of these with other papers and have handed them over long ago. I made a schedule of all the documents found upon him, and they will be on the charge sheet. I went afterwards to Tyler's residence in Harvest Road and made an examination of the papers there.
To Mr. Marshall Hall. A bundle of Stock Exchange accounts was found at Tokenhouse Buildings. The majority of them were in the name of Perryman.
WILLIAM THOMAS MOORE , recalled, produced the original affidavit signed "G. Martin" by prisoner Harris in the action of Innes against the "Financial Guardian."

MINTON SLATER , solicitor, practising as Minton Slater and Co., at 9. Wool Exchange. I acted for the defence in the action of Alex
ander Forrest Harper against the "Financial Guardian," and entered an appearance for Henry King Ablett, who was sued as the "'Finan
cial Guardian' share department." I was instructed by George Harris. I never saw Henry King Ablett. The affidavit (produced)

was, I believe, filed by my clerk, whose name is Mayo. It was pre
pared on the instructions of Harris. I do not know who swore it It purports to be sworn by H.K. Ablett. I do not know in whose handwriting the signature is. I do not know Harris's hand-writing. I do not know who went with Ablett to have it sworn. Neither I nor my clerk went with him. The ordinary course was not followed in this case. Harris called for it and took it away. The affidavit (produced) is in answer to interrogatories sworn in the same action prepared on the instructions of George Harris. It purports to be sworn by H.K. Ablett, at Budge Row. Neither myself nor my clerk was present. To my knowledge I never saw Mr. Ablett. There was a man at the office I thought was Ablett, and I was told afterwards he had gone away.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. How do you explain that when the affidavit was sworn neither you nor your clerk was present?.

Witness. He gave instructions, and asked to have the affidavit, and said he would get it sworn. I do not think it is unusual for a solicitor to let his client take a document to swear before a Commis
sioner without either himself or clerk attending with him. I did not know where he lived; his place of residence was left open. I do not think it is unusual for a solicitor to act for a gentleman in an action whom he has never seen at all. If the manager comes I do not always see the proprietor of the business.

Mr. Justice Lawrence. If that is the usual practice I advise you not to follow it in the future. If you do you will certainly get your
self into trouble.

Further examined. I filed the affidavit (produced) in the action of Lever v. the "Financial Guardian." My client in that case was George Harris. I understood that George Martin was at that time proprietor of the "Financial Guardian." I never saw George Martin for the purposes of business. He instructions for that affidavit came from George Harris. The affidavit purports to be sworn by George Martin. I have not had the opportunity of comparing the signature to see whether "George Martin" is in the same handwriting as that of "H.K. Ablett" in the other affidavits. There is a resemblance certainly, though no two letters are alike, but I cannot say they were written by the same person. I have known Perryman about 10 years, and at the time of these actions was conducting business for him. I did not introduce Harris to the Middlesex Bank when he opened an account in the name of George Martin. I gave the name of George Martin as the name of a client. I had not seen George Martin, but I had seen his representative. I did not know at the time that George Martin was George Harris.
Mr. Justice Lawrence directed that all the papers produced by witness should be sent to the Law Society.

ERNEST WYATT , accountant, Godalming branch of the Capital and Counties Bank, produced an extract from the books showing that on March 10, 1903, a £50 note was paid in to the credit of Mrs. M.L.W. Perryman, with an address at Farnborough.

THOMAS PARKINSON , works manager of the Argus Printing Com
pany, recalled, stated that the total amount of work done for Mr. Perryman was £4,500, covering a period from 1895 to 1898, and was in respect of a newspaper called the "Mining Herald." Since then there had still been an account, but smaller. For Fraser the amount of work done was £376 19s. 6d.; for Chalmers and Cox, £345 17s. 4d.; and for Herbert Smith, £931 4s. 7d.; and including Perryman's later account, the total work done was upwards of £6,000.

HERBERT KENYON BRIGHT , clerk at the head office of the London and County Bank, Lombard Street, stated that the head office had from time to time received payments into the account for the credit of the Farnborough branch account of C.W. Perryman from 1903 to 1907. The payments were principally in notes.

HENRY LISTER BASS , recalled, expressed an opinion as to certain manuscript additions and alterations upon circulars and other docu
ments being in the handwriting of Perryman.
WALTER GEORGE BLEACH , recalled, gave evidence as to cheques drawn by Perryman in his favour.

JOSEPH PERCIVAL HUDSON , of the Bank of England Note Depart
ment, gave further evidence as to Perryman's dealings with notes given him in payment of cheques over the counter.

WILLIAM CASH , Messrs. Cash and Stone, chartered accountants, 90, Cannon Street. I have had a large experience of accountancy, and particularly in connection with transactions on the Stock Exchange. I have examined the exhibits in the case of Mrs. Butcher, and find she purchased on February 16, 1906, £5,000 Canadian Pacific Stock (250 shares) at 177 1/2 cum bonus. I produce a copy of the "Stock Exchange Weekly Intelligence," which shows that the stock was quoted ex dividend on February 22, the dividend being $3 per share less tax. The letter from Ablett of March I says that the quotation has fallen away entirely owing to the general fall in securities dealt in in New York. I have taken the tape prices in the "Financial News" as issued by the Exchange Telegraph Company. The opening price on March 7 was 173 3/4, to 174 1/4, and on February 28, 175 1/2. The fall between February 16 and February 28 is in part accounted for by the fact that the shares had become ex dividend. A person who had bought cum dividend would be entitled to be credited with the dividend, which would ultimately be collected and handed over to the purchaser. Under these circumstances the three points cover on the transaction would not have run off. I take the date February 28 because the letter from the defendants contain
ing the first intimation that the shares bad fallen is dated March 1. I start from their own date. Mrs. Butcher did not send any more money. The letter signed by Ablett of March 5 asserts that "The price did fall to 173"; also that if the price fell "naturally you would be obliged to have them closed to obviate the necessity of sending more money, in the first place; and, secondly, because you were guaranteed from any further liability." In a letter of April 18 Ablett asserts that the shares were closed in default of continuance to cover

them, and in a subsequent letter he says: "The cover ran off before the Canadian Pacifics were quoted 'ex dividend,'" and "when the dividend was deducted the quotation fell to 174 1/2, the figure at which you ran off. Subsequently, on March 1, they dropped to 175 3/4." They did, as a matter of fact, but that was ex dividend. The stock being 174 1/2 ex dividend, left still three points cover. There is no allegation in the correspondence that the cover had run off before March 1. Messrs. Cooper, Walker, and Hall, Mrs. Butcher's solicitors, wrote to Ablett, asking the price at which and the date on which the cover ran off, and Ablett replied on May 3 that "when the quotation for Canadian Pacifics fell to 174 1/2 the deal ran off, as the cover became exhausted, and on March 6 they fell to 173 1/2." Mrs. Butcher offered to take up the stock, but that offer was not accepted. It is clear that on the dates Ablett mentioned the cover had not run off, if credit is taken for the amount of dividend to which Mrs. Butcher was entitled. In the case of Mrs. D'Altera of the purchase of £1,000 (50 shares) Canadian Pacific Stock, at 176 5/8 cum bonus, she re
ceived a letter in precisely the same terms as that addressed to Mrs. Butcher. On March 2 she sent £30 further cover, and from that date onwards was regularly charged contango. When she was asked to produce more cover her cover had not run off. She could have closed at a price which would have left a balance due to her, because she had £60 cover. At the end of May dividend would have been paid. The dividend was paid in April, and allowing two or three weeks for collection, there would have been due to her on my showing a balance of £75. Assuming that they still claimed the right to hold £30 cover, the stock being still open, there would have been a balance due to her then of £45, after charging her with carrying-over. When the new issue was made the shareholders got one share in every five at the price of £160, which was equivalent to a profit of $12 per $100 share. The "Stock Exchange Weekly Official Intelligence" shows the price at which the stock was made up.
Mr. F.K. Smith protested against the admission of the document Mr. Cash was called as an expert accountant, and could not give evidence on a weekly report.

Mr. Justice A.T. Lawrence said he had been informed that the document was usually accepted, but any criticism of it would certainly be looked into Prisoners were representing themselves as having been doing an honest business, and it was only possible to test that by seeing whether, if it had been done honestly, it would have resulted in a credit to the customer.

Witness. If Mrs. D'Altera had closed her account at the end of May and had taken away her cover she would have had to receive about £75, of which she had herself furnished £60. There is no ac
count giving her credit for dividends earned. In the case of Mr. Lever £1,000 Canadian Pacifics were bought at 175 1/2 on March 15. When they were closed he was entitled to a balance, and Harris several times promised a settlement. Ultimately an action was brought and £148 recovered. On April 24 he bought some Rio Tinto shares at 65 7/8 cum dividend. It does not appear that the transaction was closed. There is not material enough to show what should have been done in the case of Mrs. Pittet. In regard to Mr.

Keed's case that was a cheque for £100, sent on April 16. Exhibit 19 shows receipt of that cheque, being 1 per cent, cover on 100 Rio Tinto shares at 88 1/4 cum dividend. (Witness produced figures showing the prices of the shares at different times of the day, showing that 88 1/4 was the highest price of the day.) There were two more cheques sent by Mr. Reed, one £50 April 20 and one £350 posted April 24. The opening price on the 22nd was 90 1/2—91. On April 24 a contract was sent by Tyler's for 400 Rio Tintos at 92 3/4 cum. dividend. That was the price at 11.9, 11.45, and 12.2, and after that the price for buyers fell away, so that on the following morning the cover had run off, 91 3/4 being the opening price—in fact, it had run off at 4.9 on the previous day before the contract was sent off. I should say that the cover on the first 100 shares had run off on April 18, because at 310 on the 18th they fell to 87 1/4 (Witness particularised the rise and fall of the prices at this time, showing that the cover had run off before Mr. Reed purchased his shares. He saw no way in which de
fendants' figures could be justified.) Mr. Reed lost the whole of his £500 in dealings in Rio Tintos between April 16 and April 24, during which period there was practically a steady rise from 85 1/2 buyers to 94 1/2 buyers.
(Monday, November 4.)

Mr. Muir stated that the witness Mr. Case, who was under exami
nation when the Court last adjourned, had been taken suddenly ill, and read a medical certificate to that effect. The learned counsel further stated that he proposed to complete the other evidence the prosecution had to offer, and then counsel for the defence would elect what course they would ask his Lordship to pursue.

Mr. Marshall Hall stated that he should propose to apply for an adjournment on the ground principally that he should ask that the prosecution called all their evidence before the defendants case was opened.

chase of £1,000 worth of stock at 175 1/2, March 15, 1906. That was

the opening price. It was closed at 177 7/8 en April 9. There was no dividend in the interval. There was a meeting on March 19, at which a resolution was passed as to bonus, but it was not due until April 19. During the time this transaction was going on the shares would be quoted cum. bonus. Mr. Lever was not right when he worked out the difference of 2 3/8 as £118 15s. It should have been £23 15s., as the shares were in dollars instead of pounds. It was 2 3/8 on 5,000 dollars. Mr. Lever would only be entitled to £23 15s. and £30 deposit, even assuming the £10 on Rio Tintoe ran off. With regard to Mrs. Butcher's case, the shares were quoted ex dividend on February 22. There was an interim dividend on April 3, 3 per
cent. The dividend would be known a long time beforehand. The shares were bought on February 16, at U 7 £, the highest price of the day. In Mrs. Butcher's case the matter ended in dispute, and there was never any sale of the stock. I do not, therefore, know what price to take. The price on March 1 dropped to 173 3/4, on the 2nd they were 174 1/4, and on the 6th 1734. If Mrs. Butcher's transaction had been opened at 177 1/2, the price given in the contract, and suppos
ing it was closed on March 1 at the price Ablett contends she had run off at, there would have been nothing owing to her except her deposit. I do not think it is the proper way to reckon, contango; in this particular case it is simply a statement of interest. If the "Financial Guardian" had opened the stock themselves on the Stock Exchange at the price of February 17 (176 5/8) they would, in fact, have had to pay contango. If Mrs. Butcher was to be credited with the dividend, the other people would by entitled to charge in
terest in some shape or form.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. Interest on what?.

Witness. On the amount of the stock, at a rate; but that is exactly what I complain of, that when the final account is rendered to this lady three dividends have passed, and not one has been credited. Up to March 25 the would be entitled to two dividends, £70 less income tax. At certain times she might have closed and got a profit.

Mr. Leycester contended that the "Financial Guardian" had a right to charge interest in a transaction which was kept open for an in
definite period, where the client was to be credited with dividend on the larger amount supposed to be invested—not in this case neces
sarily, but that was the proper way of drawing up the account between the parties. Mr. Justice Lawrence saw he could not see any right accruing to them to make the charge unless they actually made a contract with someone else, and opened the stock in their own name. They must show in the circular some bargain by which a sum was to be paid, in order to entitle them to charge their client with the interest.
Witness. I should like to point out that the circular deliberately contemplates the purchase of the stock, otherwise, the dividend can never be collected.

Re-examined. The reason I said that Herbert Smith's account, London and Joint Stock Bank, looked more like a legitimate business was that there are cheques drawn for considerable sums about the middle and end of each month, which looks like a Stock Exchange account—a stockbroker's banking account. There are also larger sums paid in cheques through that account than through the others. With the others, I am struck by the fact that there are very large sums drawn out in notes and gold. In the ordinary way it is most unusual to find accounts of the present day where such a large pro
portion are in bank notes and coin.

To Mr. Justice Lawrence. With active shares it is not true that the quotation ex-dividend is the same as cum. dividend. Rio Tintos and Canadian Pacifies are very active; variations occur every hour or so. It must follow as a matter of course with active shares that when they became ex-dividend they decline to the extent of the dividend declared. There may be extraneous reasons why the price should not fall by the amount of dividend, but taking the example which your lordship asked for, and which I turned up and put in, the variation corresponds exactly. In my opinion it is less true with international shares to say that the price does not change when they are sold ex-dividend, because, they are dealt with over such a large area, and there are more people interested in their fluctuations.
(Wednesday, November 6.)
JOHN OTTAWAY , recalled. I found cheque book of Eraser's account with the Economic Bank (produced) at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings.
RICHARD EDWARD CAREY , clerk to Economic Bank. I product "cheque book issue book" of my bank. (To Mr. Marshall Hall) I did not make the entries myself. (Evidence objected to and rejected)

H. L. BASS, recalled. I have compared the numbers of £16,000 Bank of England notes with the numbers shown by Herbert Smith's account, and find they correspond; also the numbers of notes paid into Pern-man's account from May, 1902, to the end of 1903, amount
ing to £3.095, and find that they have all been paid out of Herbert Smith's account.
Cross-examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. I have been acquainted with Perryman's account at my bank for about 15 years—very large amounts have been paid in in cash and notes.

Mr. Marshall Hall submitted that there was no evidence against Perryman on the counts for obtaining, and that such counts should be struck out; that there might be evidence of a common object, but there was no evidence to obtain by false pretences or of any obtaining by false pretences.

Mr. F. E. Smith submitted that there was no evidence against Tyler with regard to the circulars of Chalmers and Cox, "Financial Guardian," or Herbert Smith. He referred to the case of Revs. Warren and others (page 1022), and submitted that the prosecution ought to be severed and the further indictments quashed, as was done in that case by the Common Serjeant.
(Held. There being evidence of conspiracy involved that there was evidence of acts done in pursuance of that conspiracy.)
(Defence.)

CHARLES WILBRAHAM PERRYMAN (prisoner, on oath). I have known Herbert Smith 15 years. I have known Tyler since 1895 or 1896 when he was director of one or more companies with which I was connected. Harris became my clerk in about 1886, when the "Finan
cial Observer" was being published. Hawkee was sub-editor of that paper. It ceased to exist in 1896. Herbert Smith was in the tea trade. I had not seen him for some 10 or 12 Years when I met him accidentally in 1900 in an inside stockbrokers office with whom I did business, where he came to look at the tape and get prices. Harris was in the employment of that firm, and I learnt that Smith was working with his brother, who was a stockbroker near Lombard Street. 43, Moorgate Street, was the office of two or three public companies, of which Tyler and Atkins (who is now dead) and Fardell were directors. Tyler was going to South Africa, and I wanted office room as I had large interests in companies, and I arranged with him to make my headquarters at 43, Moorgate Street. I was a director of Hannan's King Gold Mining Company and the Tinga Valley Gold Mining Company. In 1902 Smith proposed to start an outside stock
broker's business, and I agreed to back him up. He than took offices at 80, Lombard Street, but as the offices at 43, Moorgate Street were larger it was arranged to transfer the company work to Lombard Street and conduct the stockbroker's business at 43, Moorgate Street Circular of August 1, 1902, has one or two words written upon it which I believe are in my handwriting, and an alteration of the date to the "16th" from the "l st" August. No circular of that date has been sent out. I may have trimmed up some circulars for Herbert Smith. I financed Smith at the start to a very small extant—he did not want any further help. I had a large Stock Exchange business and I introduced him to a broker to obtain cover; the runner of that broker introduced him to another firm also. As a rule, outside brokers run stock against the client in their own protection and to give security to the client. Accounts are delivered fortnightly. Smith's system gave this advantage to the client who bought stock under the cover system that, if the stock fell, the client was not liable further, and he would have notice from Smith before the ac
count was closed and so would have, a day to provide further cover if he preferred, thus keeping his interest in the stock and rescuing

hit first cover. I did considerable business with Herbert Smith on my own account, with the object also of increasing his credit and enlarging the volume of his business. I was in the habit of paying my differences in bank notes in preference to cheques. (A Urge number of accounts were gone through with the witness to show the way banknotes were dealt with, also a number of payments to clients.) On account day I attended at Herbert Smith's office and dissected his account to find out the bargains made on my behalf and on his, and I paid my differences to him. Herbert Smith died in October. 1905 Previous to and after that date Harris was conducting his business Some 15 or 16 days before Herbert Smith's death, Harris transferred the banking account, or, rather, he opened a new banking account with the London Joint Stock Bank in the name of Herbert Smith. I knew that Harris was going to carry on the business in the name of Herbert Smith. Harris and I saw Smith at St. Bartholomew's Hospital. Smith raised no objection at all. Harris got permission to continue the business in the name of Smith. Harris continued the business under the name of Herbert Smith. The account at the Lon
don Joint Stock Bank was opened on October 5, 1904. That account appears to have been carried on in the same way by Harris frost October, 1903, to June, 1904, I saw Mrs. Herbert Smith only twice. She came to see me by appointment. I think the dates she gave were about correct. I then had an interview with her, and told her that the business was hers, as she was the widow, and asked her what she would like to be done with it Harris was introduced to her on that first occasion. Harris made the appointment for me to see her, and she was then told by me that the business belonged to her—that Harris had been managing it alter her husbands death in the same way as when her husband was alive. I thought she knew all about it. She did not say she knew nothing about it then. She said she would consider the question, and ask her brothers. That interview was six months before the letter of June 28, 1904, was written. She did not know, as she stated, that Herbert Smith had taken offices at 80, Lombard Street. I received the letter of June 28, 1904, from Mrs. Herbert Smith (Exhibit 229), in which she says, "The enclosed has just arrived. Will you be good enough to see that I am not troubled again with application for rent." That was the rent of 80, Lombard Street. The letter continues: "It is very painful to receive letters addressed to my poor husband. I think it would be better not to trade under his name." Up to that time Mrs. Herbert Smith had not made any objection at all on her part as to not trading under her husband's name. I answered that letter, and asked her to come and see me, which she did within two days of June 27. She then said the same as she says in her letter, namely. that she did not desire the business to be carried on any more under her husband's name. Harris was there at the same time, and I said that under the circumstances it must be stopped, and it was stopped the next day. The Last account with the bank was the following day June 30. Bleach's statement about putting up the name—that Harris

asked him and that he consulted with me, and that I told him to do it, is not accurate—my words were, "I had no objection." I was then paying the rent at 27, Sun Street. Bleach naturally thought it right to ask me whether I had any objection to the name going up, and I said "No." I did not in any way suggest that the name of "Herbert Smith" should be put up in Sun Street; it did not origi
nate from me. This was following on the interview with Mrs. Smith. The reason why assented to the name of "Herbert Smith" going up was that, although the business was shut down as from June 30, a good many accounts had to be cleared up—it took six months or more to clear it up. There were bargains open which had to be shut, and accounts had to be finished with. The exhibits in the letter-book which has bean exhibited show that only two letters were ever written from Sun Street. Dealing with the Joint Stock Bank account from the dates that have been given, out of a total of £13,039 paid in, according to Mr. Cash's figures, a sum of £11,519 was paid out to clearing bankers, and over the counter only £1,506 15a. 0d. Out of that amount £150 came to my account by way of notes. This is Herbert Smith's "No. 2" account. I have looked through Herbert Smith's account, and I find that £4,565 was said into his account in notes, and £199 0s. 11d. paid in in coin. Out of a total of £4,764 paid in in notes and cash, I provided quite £4,000. I was financing Harris, if necessary. I had to occasionally, because he had not got enough money to pay his accounts. Harris was carrying on business in exactly the same way as Smith did—he was protecting himself. He had an account for that purpose in the same way. For the pur
pose of assisting Harris I let him take some of my Stock Exchange accounts with one broker. Referring to Mr. Cash's figures, I, find payments out to stockbrokers between October 5, 1903, and June, 1904, totaling to £5,879 17s. 10d. After Harris had closed these transactions of Herbert Smith's I never did any business on my own in the name of Herbert Smith. I never had any direct association or responsibility with the firm of Herbert Smith, and never controlled it it is not true to suggest, as has been suggested by the detective in his information, that I was practically "Herbert Smith." In 1904 a bankruptcy issue was directed to be tried as to whether I was "Herbert Smith." That came on before Mr. Registrar Gifford, and lasted about a fortnight. I was represented by counsel and examined and cross-examined for days. The result of that was that Mr. Re
gistrar Gifford delivered a considered judgment in my favour. That decision was appealed from in the Court of Appeal. (Mr. Muir submitted that this was not admissible in evidence. Mr. Marshall Hall submitted it was evidence, inasmuch as one of the issues now being tried was practically whether Perryman, at this period, was "Herbert Smith." If he (the learned counsel) could prove that that was a mere resjudicator it was admissible. Mr. Justice A. T. Lawrence said that it was not resjudicata between the present parties, and that the Crown was not bound by any finding of the Court of Appeal. He did not see how it was admissible. Mr. Marshall Hall said that
his real reason was that he did not want it to be suggested that he was keeping it back in any way, and that he would leave it for cross-examination if counsel for the prosecution so desired.)

To Mr. Marshall Hall. I have looked through the letter book 13, one of the many letter books found at Tokenhouse Buildings, and there is not any letter there in my handwriting. I have also looked through all the 10 or 12 letter books, and there is no letter in my handwriting. There are a great many accounts that are not in my handwriting. Those that are in my handwriting are the ones that I dissected from the accounts received from stockbrokers when I dissected the amount. In taking out the amount I took out for Smith the other items that appeared; they are protected accounts that had been opened with stockbrokers.

To Mr. Justice Lawrence. On pay day there were two or three brokers' accounts, which bad to be dissected to see what my share was, and also in those brokers' accounts there are coverings for some of these clients, which necessitated an account being made out iden
tical with the statement in the stockbrokers' accounts; so when I took out my portion of the account I took out certain other accounts there for the purpose of sending to Herbert Smith's clients. The ac
counts that I have seen in this book are ones that were coverings and appear in the accounts that the stockbrokers tendered to Herbert Smith.

To Mr. Marshall Hall. As to those that I have called out to the Judge, where it says "Paid," I have traced cheques out of Herbert Smith's account; they total to between £900 and £1,000, in this book, paid out to clients between October 9 and December 11, 1903. With regard to Sun Street, the only letters that went from there appear to be letters of April 5 and 10. My connection with Bleach was in this manner. I suppose that 20 years ago I knew Bleach's father and elder brother, who was foreman printer at the printing works where my paper was published. He died, I think, about 1892 or 1893, and then his brother, the witness Bleach, took his place, and after the "Financial Observer" and "Mining Herald" was stopped Peach has only had from me company work or my own private work. He was an old servant, and he had gone out of his way to get him work. Since he had had no regular income from his (witness's) paper he had been very poor. Witness had continually lent him money. With regard to the 125 cheques, as to which he originally swore were paid to him, that is not so, because all the earlier ones were paid to his father or his brother, because they were matters connected with the printing of the "Financial Observer." Bleach said on the second examination that they amounted in all to about £300, of which £60 or £70 were cheques he had from me to change for himself, and the balance, £230, had to be accounted as money lent. (To the Judge.) With regard to the changing of cheques to which he referred, what happened was that witness used to lend Bleach his post-dated cheque for £5 or £6 for his accommodation, and he gave me the money when it became

due. It is wrong to say I was hard up and wanted money. The money I lent Bleach was to get him out of trouble. I not only paid the rent and the rent of the machine, but I paid the rent of Bleach's private bouse when the brokers were share. The total amount during the period we are dealing with, according to Bleach's statement, was £200, but I thought it was very much less. That worked out to somewhere between 15a. and a £1 a week. With reference to Sun Street, as Bleach wanted work, the original idea was that we should restart the "Financial Observer," of which I still own the copyright—not the "Financial Guardian." There was no object in my personally starting any other paper, as I was rather well-known in connection with the "Financial Observer." The next thing was where the offices should be. Bleach said he had had a convenient place offered to him in Sun Street, Finsbury, and he suggested taking it at £30 a year. I talked over the question of plant and machi
nery with Bleach, and he arranged to get both from a large firm who did this kind of business, and to have it on the hire system. I undertook to pay the rent of the offices and Bleach got the machinery and plant in. It was only adapted for newspaper work. Bleach did not get much work in, and went on for about a month or so, and then I abandoned the idea, saying that I did not want to be bothered over the paper any more. I told-Bleach that if he liked to keep on the printing works he could have the benefit of the amount that I had paid on the machinery. Bleach kept them on for a year as he stated. The alleged conversation that Bleach spoke to with re
ference to some case pending in the Courts was absolutely untrue. Bleach has never spoken to me at any period anywhere about the matter in question. I was attending the Court on subpoena, and saw Bleach in the Court, but had never spoken to him in the Court or near the Court. I was appearing on the same side that Bleach was. There was no question whether I was Ablett or anybody else. The case was not heard, and there was no occasion for Bleach making the suggestion he did. There was an Ablett. I have seen Ablett. I have never posed as Ablett or represented myself to be Ablett, or been accused by anybody as being Ablett. Bleach has been repeatedly in the company of two policemen. I and my friends have seen him in public-houses. The whole tale is a myth. I have known Parkinson many years. He or his firm did work for me in connection with the "Finan
cial Observer." I should call him an unintelligent witness. I think he has made a mistake when he says I have given him orders on ac
count of these people. Probably ha is confusing in his mind the circumstance that at some time, for some months, or weeks, he had orders through me for work which has been paid for, and he is simply muddling what the orders were. I knew of the Lombard Financial Corporation, but I have never had the least to do with it, nor with the business of the "Financial Guardian," either under the name of Ablett or Martin or Wood. I had not the least to do with the business of "Tyler and Co." I did not know it existed.

I have never in my life been to Pinner's Hall, and never had any con
nection other than I have described with Herbert Smith or with any other business excepting that I knew the Lombard Financial Corpora
tion was run by Herbert Smith. Part of the coverings that Herbert Smith did were as to the Lombard Financial Corporation clients, and part of the notes that are traced out by Mr. Cash from Fraser's ac
counts to Smith were on account of the very losses incurred for the Lombard Financial Corporation clients, which Mr. Cash will find were taken out on pay days. We did not know that Mr. Cash would be a witness until just before this trial started, and we did not know what he was going to say. The prosecution were put under an obliga
tion to give us notice of new evidence by October 10. Mr. Cash has made a great fuss with regard to £70 drawn out on March 11 in notes and traced to Herbert Smith's account, but if he will turn no Ellis's account of March 11 be will find that that £70 went into Ellis's account and was paid out of Percy Ellis's account on different Stock Exchange transactions that were coverings for clients. The Lombard Financial Corporation is at 80, Lombard Street. That was started on or about July 9, 1902. The offices were taken by the real Herbert Smith from Dr. Bennett. I never gave any guarantee to Dr. Bennett; I never saw him in my life or wrote to him. I was not in any way responsible for Herbert Smith taking those premises. It has not been suggested that there is anything wrong with the Lombard Financial Corporation that I know of. I have known Parkinson for many years. I introduced business to him. I never gave him any orders for printing for Chalmers and Cox; he got them from Hawkes. I knew Hawkes was running Chalmers and Cox. With reference to the quasi guarantee given to Parkinson. What happened was this, Mr. Parkinson came to see me, saying that he was in serious trouble with his managing director, and the directors of the company he re
presented. I knew some of them. He said there was a chance of his entirely losing his situation. I asked him what was the matter. He said his instructions were not to give anybody more than one circu
lar credit—that is to say, the last circular had to be paid for before a new one was issued, or printed, by the Argus Company. He said that on my recommendation of Hawkes and Smith he had extended the credit and that they had not paid. I said I could not afford to lose my credit with the Argus (which was unlimited), and as I did not want to see him lose his situation I would do my best to stir no Hawkes and Smith to pay the accounts, and if he did not get paid in two months' time I would see that his firm lost nothing by it. The three accounts Parkinson referred to were Chalmers and Cox, Herbert Smith, and Fraser. I saw Hawkes at the first opportunity and pressed him to pay his account with the Argus, and he did so. Hawkes is Chalmers and Cox. I pressed Harris to pay the other one, and be could not afford to do it. The other two accounts were both practi
cally Herbert Smith and Fraser. Harris not paying, I did. I be
came liable under my guarantee, and I paid. The only cheques out of my stolen cheque book that they have got, paid to the Argus—stolen

by the police—are those paid on account of the guarantee. I never paid them one farthing at any date on account of these accounts or circulars except under the guarantee I had given to Parkinson, and they were only paid later than the date of the guarantee. I never paid Parkinson's firm anything in respect of work done subsequent to the date of the guarantee. I have examined the books of the Argus, and find they did no work for any of them after September, 1904, the date of the guarantee. I think Parkinson said they did, but I think he is muddled. The copy of the guarantee set out in Parkinson's evidence is ah exact copy of the guarantee I gave. The Argus Company, through Messrs. Lewis and Lewis, sued me on my guarantee in the month of December, 1904, before my guarantee had become operative. I do not remember whether I put in any defence to it. They got judgment; I think we agreed it. I was then served with a bankruptcy notice, which was set aside on the ground that it did not tally with the description in the judgment. They put in the bankruptcy notice "Trading as Herbert Smith." That was dismissed. In the bundle of circulars (Exhibit 204) there are all sorts of things—letters, draft circulars, and so on. The draft circular covering several pages is in Hawkess handwriting. What has been sworn to be my handwriting consists practically of the addition or alteration of a few words. Hawkes was a very proficient circular writer, and a very good newspaper writer of large experience. I should think he in over 70 years old; he may be 80. On page 12 of this there art the words, "just declared" in my writing. The explanation of that is this—that these are evidently drank circulars and draft letters of Hawkess; and if he had asked me (as no doubt he did) to make a grammatical altera
tion or an alteration affecting finance; I did do it; he is not the only person I have done it for. I am not sure that anything I have altered here has been used—probably not. The alterations come to nothing; I think they are only a word, or a line, or a dot. With regard to 90, Lombard Street I gave a reference for Herbert Smith (Exhibit 191). It is dated as being received on July 6, 1902. That was the time when Herbert Smith was thinking of taking No. 80, Lombard Street for the. purposes of his own business. I had forgotten all about the circumstance until the prosecution brought it forward. I have given references for other people. The other reference was given by Harms (Exhibit 192). The Kalgoorlie Company was a com
pany I had been associated with years before. The paper is dated July 15, 1890. It is evidently a paper that had been prepared before 1900. There is a wonderful lot of paper, but there are very little alterations in it. There are one or two figures put in here—what last year's total amount of income from the railway was. I pot that in; I had been asked to do it. Mr. Bass is right in saying there are a number of minute alterations in my writing in that bundle. I have 'lotted an "i" and crossed a "t" I knew there was an account of Fraser at the Economic Bank. The only way I can explain as to how some of the memoranda on some of the counterfoils is in my handwriting is that it would be coincident with a Stock Exchange

Pay Day, when finance had to be arranged in some shape or form somewhere, and there was always a little scrimmage or squeeze to pay the obligations and finance one from the other, and as Herbert Smith treated the Lombard Corporation as his own account—the same as his own business—probably I should not be at all surprised that I filled up a cheque; I believe I have filled up some of Herbert Smith's cheques before now. (To the Judge.) I think Fraser is Herbert Smith; I am not sure about it. (To Mr. Marshall Hall.) I had not anything to do with the carrying on of any business by anybody in the name of Fraser. The cheque not turned down, which have been sworn to be my writing. I think are in my writing. There are one or two queries. I never gave any orders for any circulars for the Lombard Financial Corporation. I had an office at 41, Charing Cross Road, which I gave up a year last September, where I used to keep books, etc.
(Thursday, November 7.)

CHARLES WILBRAHAM PERRYMAN (recalled) further examined by Mr. Marshall Hall. Herbert Smith's account with the London Joint Stock Bank was practically closed on June 29. There was a pay
ment in on June 30 of £30, and three small cheques were subse
quently drawn, leaving a balance of £11 4s. 9d., which was subse
quently transferred under a garnishee order. The business of Chal
mers and Cox was Hawkes'e and was in no way suggested or inspired by me and I had nothing to do with financing the business. The office at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings was taken from Dove by Hawkes. Dove sent for me and asked me if I knew Mr. Hawkes. I said that I had known him for ten years as a respectable man and thought he would keep his obligations, and I said I would do what I could to see that his rent was paid, but I gave no guarantee whatever. As a net result I was not called upon at all under that so-called guarantee. Mr. Hawkes paid all the rent. When Hawkes had left, and some time after these same premises had been taken over by Harris, I gave Harris two of my cheques for £18 15s. each drawn in favour of Dove. Doves evidence as to a cheque previously given by me, but never cashed, is correct. I gave a cheque for £56 5s. I do not know who paid the money. I only know it was paid. Whatever expression Mr. Dove may have used, in point of fact no guarantee was ever given by me. The words I used were, "I will see that it is all right." Hawkes did borrow some money of me about the time he went in. I saw him very occasionally. He came and bought shares of me, and also un
covered a small number of stocks with me. He asked my advice upon financial matters. He also did stocks with Smith. He ran his busi
ness honestly and paid his accounts. I might not see Hawkes for six months, or I might run against him two or three times a week. I never went to Tokenhouse Buildings when the business of Chalmers and Cox was being carried on there between 1903 and 1905, and did not give orders for circulars. I used to see Hawkes at 43, Moorgate Street. I did not go to Tokenhouse Buildings until after February

1905. For years past I have advised people in respect of their circus
lars. I used to advise George Gregory, the largest outside broker we have ever had. I used to write for him, and I used to advise other people. I was supposed to have some knowledge, having had 20 years' experience of newspaper work. There is a very large honest business being done by outside broken at the present time.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. What does that meant "Honest business" is such a comprehensive term.

Witness. Outside broken have been dubbed "bucket shops," which is presumably an offensive term for the purpose of assuming that they are fraudulent institutions, but there is a great number of sound, honest, outside broken who conduct legitimate businesses now and have done for the last 20 yean to my knowledge.

Mr. Justice Lawrence. Does that mean places when they specu
late in differences, but speculate in differences honestly?.

Witness. No, large transactions in genuine shares and the trans
ference both by sales and purchases of genuine shares. An outside broker's is not only a place where people speculate in differences, but thousands and thousands of pounds, hundreds of thousands of pounds, pass in the legitimate transfer of shares. I think every outside broker does both businesses. Naturally no outside broker confines himself to any particular class of business. As a rule he takes any business that comes to him. If a man wants to buy shares he buys them and deliver them to him; if he wants to speculate in dif
ferences, he speculates for him. A shareholder will, I presume, sell to anybody if he is paid. I have received money from Hawkes, but after this lapse of time it is rather difficult to give particulars. Generally speaking, if Hawkes has 'paid me money it has been 'small amounts advanced on loan; other amounts have been for shares sold, and there would be cover on stocks that might be open. The offices at Tokenhouse Buildings consisted of two rooms and a lobby. From February, 1906, to Christmas, 1906, I used to give assistance occa
sionally at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. I knew Harris was carrying on an outside broker's business. The name of the "Financial Guardian" was on the door, and I saw a man there named Ablett. The name of the "Financial Guardian" was not up in Hawkes's time. The person I saw as Ablett was of different identity from Harris. I should think I saw Ablett half a dosed times; it did not run long after I font saw him; I should think about two months. In 1905 I used to see people at Tokenhouse Buildings by appointment. So far as I knew the business of the "Financial Guardian" was an honest business. I knew nothing of the existence of a man named Martin in connection with it. I cannot say when I first knew that Harris and Martin were identical. I eventually moved some papers and things there from 41, Charing Cross Road. I think that was in Sep
tember, 1906, shortly before I took a room for myself, on which were the letters "C. W. P." Those paper, weighing about 2 cwt., and in
cluding some old "Financial Observe," some cheque books, and two tin boxes of private paper are now in the hands of the police.

I also removed there some papery I had stored at Old Jewry. The draft account sent to Mrs. D'Altera is in my handwriting. This is not a Stock Exchange account at all. It is a calculation of so many days' interest on a certain amount of money on contango. It has happened more than once when I have been there that Harris has asked me to check his making up of the contangoes, and I have checked them while I have been waiting. What happened about this particular account was that I found it was wrong, and I wrote it out again. The initials H.K.A. (Ablett) and G.M. (George Martin) were copied from the original account. I have done the same thing on other occasions. At the end of 1906, or the early part of January, 1907, I entered into an agreement with Dove to take two separate rooms at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings as from December 25. 1900. They were in quite another part of the building. At the time I was living in the country. Harris had been an old servant of mine and used to do odd jobs for me when I was not in town, such as going to the stores and paying accounts. I used to give him cheques in blank. Sometimes my cheques were filled in by Miss Mabel Long, who was Harris's clerk. That happened in the case of the account of a stockbroker named Allen on one occasion when I was going away. I did not know the amount of the account, and gave a cheque to Harris to be filled in. As to the statement that my two "C. W. P." rooms were unfurnished, I cannot think why that should have been said. They were furnished as much as was wanted. There were three chairs, a flap table, a roll-top desk, and a settee, and they are there now. There was only one door to the two rooms. They were totally distinct from the "Financial Guardian" offices, and no use was made of them by anybody else except myself. My papers were not removed from the "Financial Guardian" offices, because I had entered into an agreement to do my new offices up; they wanted some carpentry work, painting, and cleaning. I am still a tenant of these offices. I have taken out some of the accounts for stock that I opened for Harris. The total amount opened by Cutliffe, Lea, and Co. from the middle of March to the middle of November. 1905, was £120,386 Ss. 3d., and the loss in differences paid was £837 5s. 4d. The account with Waiter Allen runs from August, 1905, to December, 1906. The amount of stock opened was £349.486. and the amount of differences paid was £2,560.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. What did he receive in differences? They cannot all have been such bad bargains.

Witness. I am afraid it was a time when markets continued fall
ing, and it was all on the wrong side. Prices in some instances are hall what they were two years ago. To take a well-known instance, Brighton "A" have fallen 50 points in six months.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. The wonder is that with your experience you do not foresee these falls. You always buy for the rise.

Witness. If we could only job backwards we should all be mil
lionaires, but we cannot foresee. Personally, I have made money on the Stock Exchange by being a "bear" not by being a "bull." All

these bargains were effected in my own name. Union Pacific have fallen 90 points, and holders of £1,000 stock would have lost £900 in a year. Southern Pacifics have dropped 35 points, or 40 per cent. Caledonian Railways have dropped 50 per cent.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. Do not let us have too many harrowing details of this sort.

Witness. In another account, that of Jakes and Co., the stocks opened (between September and November, 1905, were £20,000, and the loss paid was £498. In the case of C. J. Ellis, commencing August, 1906, the stocks were running up to April, the time of this charge, and amounted to £39,981, and the losses paid are £773 19s. 4d. To the best of my belief the majority of this was Harris's stock. When I took the "C. W. P." offices I was negotiating two companies. This charge has had something to do with their not having been brought out, but the companies also dragged because the markets were bad. Mrs. Strick was my clerk from 1886 to 1896, and left me to get married. An extraordinary thing is that I met her outside policeman Ottaway's premises, in Old Jewry, about a fort
night before the trial began, and she said, "I have been to the police." It is not true that I ever asked her to take in letters in the name of Ablett. Tyler told me he had found suitable offices at 79 1/2, Gracechurch Street, but Smiles who was acting for the landlord, would not let without a guarantee, which I gave. There was some trouble about the superior landlord, and I demanded the guarantee back, but did not get it. After that Tyler went to 16 and 17, Great St. Helens, and was joined by Gibbs. Gibbs had had 30 years ex
perience on the Stock Exchange in Industrial shares. Grosvenor, a friend of Gibbs, was going to assist in the business. I had nothing to do with the taking of the offices, and was never there while Gibbs was there. Mr. Muir's statement in his opening speech that I guaranteed the rent is absolutely untrue. In December, 1906, Tyler came to me at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings, and told me Gibbs was leav
ing and going back to the Stock Exchange. Tyler also said he had established the business, and thought it would be a prosperous one, and asked if I would help him, He wanted to borrow a little money, and he also wanted shares for the purpose of dealing in. I lent him £30, and subsequently another £30 for his rent. With reference to the circular of Messrs. Pope and Westlake, I then owned, and still own, two founders' shares in the Fullers Earth Union. I knew If there was a willing buyer if I could find a willing seller I could make a profit between the two, and for the purpose of finding a seller I selected Tyler as intermediary, as I thought it was the class of busi
ness he required. As a result he purchased Lord Kilmorey's share for £50 and I gave him £55 for it, and resold it to Pope and West-lake by arrangement for £89. When their cheque for £87 2s. arrived I asked Tyler to give me an exchange cheque for it, which I cashed for notes, yet the police have put down these notes which they traced to my bank as being part of the proceeded of Tyler's alleged frauds against Chef parties, whereas they bad the counterfoil in their hands

and could see this was a mere exchange. It shows the way they have persecuted we. As Tyler then owed me £60 I credited him with £55, the price of the share, and he gave me £5 to clear the matter up. I was arrested on June 27, but my letters and cheque-books were stolen on June 11, 16 days before any charge was made against me. As regards my habit of changing cheques into cash I produce a large number from various customers. I have evidence as to over £11,000, but that does not represent one half, because people do not always keep their cheques, and I cannot trace them. When I was at Tokenhouse Buildings I made some alterations to circulars once or twice.

Cross-examined by Mr. Muir. I began to attend at 43, Moorgate Street in 1900 for about three times a week for an hour in the morn
ing. I was then looking after some companies. One of them was the Rand Roodeport Gold Mining Co., which is still alive. The officials of that company were Mr. Tyler, Mr. Atkins, Mr. Fardell, and Colonel Thompson. I was only interested as a shareholder. My name did not appear as a public officer of the company. Another was the Teign valley Mining Company, which I think has been re
constructed. It has never paid any dividend. I was a director of that, and I think Mr. Ashworth was. There was a third, whose name I have forgotten. Another company was the Kalgoorlie Prince, which is still in existence. I had some shares. I believe it is earning money. I have ceased to be a shareholder for three or four years. None of the companies paid a dividend in my time. I believe there were two secretaries. One was named Nicholas; I forget the name of the other. I think there was one clerk. Harris in 1901 or 1904 became secretary of the Rand Roodeport. It was a few months after that that Smith appeared upon the scene. He came there with the idea of starting this business. He consulted me about it on and off for about two years. We talked the matter over, but I do not sup
pose I advised him to do it. Smith had been in the tea trade, and had become bankrupt. He had not much capital to start a business with. I should say the business of an outside broker was not a risky but a safe business. I do not endorse the suggestion that it is con
ducted oy the outside broker against clients. It does not follow that if the clients win the outside broker must lose; they may both quite easily win at the same time, and very often do. I do not agree to the proposition that the outside broker's profits are limited to the amount of the cover. If you say the client's liability is so limited that is perfectly true, but the broker cannot always win what the client loses; sometimes the cover lost may go into three or four hands. I consider the position of the outside broker a safe one, not necessarily at the expense of the public. It may be at the expense of the Stock Exchange. As far as I knew Herbert Smith's business was a model of what an outside broker's ought to be, I did not encourage Smith to start the outside broking business, I said I would back him. That is not necessarily encouraging him. It was his desire, not mine. The first thing in starting an outside

broker's business is to draft circulars. Smith did that for himself. He was a good writer, one of the best circular writers I ever saw in my life. Neither Harris nor Hawkes drafted circulars for Herbert Smith that I know of. The usual way is to copy some other broker's circular. I do not know that I gave him any to copy. Atkins was the principal man at 43, Moorgate Street. He was a director. I believe I was on the voters' list. I cannot tell how I got there. Miss Long was Smith's clerk. Harris was manager of the business from the beginning. Herbert Smith took an active part, and at far ss I know was there daily. I cannot name any person who is here as a witness who has ever seen Herbert Smith. I do not believe that Bleach saw him only once, and I think that the story that Bleach had to have Smith pointed out to him by a lady clerk is an Invention. As to Mrs. Strick having only seen him once I do not suppose she has ever been there more than once. I never saw her there at all. Jessie Oyler was employed there about twelve months. If she thought Harris was Smith I cannot help that. There was no necessity for Smith to go into the office where the young lady clerk was, and she might have been there twenty years without seeing him. Besides she sat with her face to the window, and would not see anybody com
ing into the room. Parkinson, who identified the photograph of Smith, used to come about once in three months. As to the statement of Mr. Gash that £12,000 came into, the business, it passed through the banking account, but that is not money coming into the business. I consider the foot that Smith only had 4s. a day quite consistent with his controlling a business of this magnitude. With regard to my own position towards the business, I simply dealt through Herbert Smith. I was his client. I opened stocks for myself on the Stock Exchange, and they were debited to Smith's account, and the con
tracts went to Herbert Smith, in the name of Herbert Smith. Herbert Smith also opened stocks in his own name for his own protection. I met the brokers at Smith's office, and the stocks were put down to him with the knowledge of the brokers. I never gave orders to stock
brokers to cover for Herbert Smith. The volume of business Smith did gave him credit. I attended on pay-day, and picked out the stocks that were mine. Without a technical knowledge of the neces
sities of this business it is very difficult for anybody to follow it. I hare technical knowledge, but counsel have not very great know
ledge, end his Lordship is rather strange-to it. Herbert Smith, either by himself or through Harris, opened stock on the Stock Ex
change to protect his clients, and I opened stock on the Stock Ex
change through the same broker who was dealing for Herbert Smith, and those contracts went down to Herbert Smith's account. When pay-day came round I had to take up my three or four loans in order to know what I had to pay or receive, and the balance of the account belonged to Herbert Smith. If there was a profit on the account I got it from Herbert Smith, why in turn got it from the broker; if there was a loss the broker had to look to Smith for it. I was there paying differences and looking after the accounts. It is not. true

that I took only notes and gold in payment; I also took cheques. I had a bad a strong preference for gold and notes. I do not accept the proposition that the broker might have to sue Smith, and might get nothing. I do not suppose I gained anything by not dealing with the broker in my own name. I did it for the purpose of ex
tending Smith's credit. I suppose that as a consequence Smith got better terms from the brokers. He did not get anything from me for doing it, except my assistance. I am not prepared to say that there are no cheques drawn in my name. I do not at all see that if a person in my position was trying to carry on business in the name of Herbert Smith, and desired to conceal his identity, he would have adopted the method which I adopted. I have drawn cheques in Smith's favour. My cheques have been stolen by the police.

Mr. Muir appealed to the court that the police should not be sub
jected to offensive epithets of the kind.

Mr. Justice Lawrence. I think it is very offensive and very un
wise.

Witness. I cannot describe it by any other word. I paid Smith thousands of pounds. I had the settlements with Herbert Smith about every fortnight, on which we were able to tell on the contract notes how much was his and how much mine, and so a payment would be made on one side or the other. If there were £100 or £1,000 due to me he would make it up by handing me a number of cheques or notes, etc. I do not think I ever got gold in large amounts from him. The money was paid into my bank, as a matter of fact, by one of my clerks. It does not follow they were all fortnightly settlements; they would in some instances be on pay-days, sometimes not. There is confirmation to be found of amounts paid through Smith to me on paydays. They did not represent the whole of the payments from Smith to me, because it was not always paid on the pay-days. Your question as to what there would be in my banking account to show I was not conducting the business of Herbert Smith and receiving the payments made to his business is not a tenable suggestion; it is a hypothetical question, which I cannot answer. I do not see why any
thing should be shown in my account one way or the other. The fact that I acknowledge receiving cheques from Smith is sufficient. If you think because I have received cheques of Herbert Smith that therefore the business of Herbert Smith is mine, that is a hypothesis you must establish in some other way. You can find instances where Smith's cheques have gone into my account. It means nothing more than that Smith owed me the account, and paid me by those amounts. If £1,000 went into my account from Smith, from June to December, 1902, it showed he owed me the money. You say £125 only went into Smith's account; I do not know that it is so. Letter produced is from Smith to Atkins, acknowledging receipt of £100, signed by Herbert Smith. I do not think it is signed with a stamp. I have heard there was a stamp with Herbert Smith's signature. In the paying-in slip of the same date, "£100 Henry Atkins" is in my handwriting.

To Mr. Justice Lawrence. The reason my paying-in book was at 43, Moorgate Street was in case anything happened to be paid in. I kept it there so that if any money was owing to me I might know it was paid in and have a record. It was generally kept at home. When Herbert Smith owed me money—it might be lord several different things—I arranged with him that it was paid into my account as soon as he got it. I knew it came from him at the time; I do not know now. Perhaps he would any so, or one of his darks, or they would give me the book. The identification is obvious. If it came from Smith I knew it at the time, because I should be wanting it and asking for it, and they would take care to say that it had been paid in. That is my knowledge that the money had been paid in. Numerous amounts and names of payments in were put to witness, amounting to £959 15s., from October to December, 1902, the great majority of which were said by witness to be in Harris's writing, the exceptions being in that of a clerk.)

To Mr. Muir. If £959 went into my account from Herbert Smith, and £125 went to his account, it simply showed that he owed me the money. There was £900 paid in apparently in the last three weeks of Herbert Smith's life; that was money he owed me. If he did not, it is a matter for argument whether the money ought to have gone to his widow; it ought, I think, to have gone to hit creditors. The widow had every opportunity of seeing whether Smith owed me the money; the books were there. I offered that she should take the whole business if she liked at the time of Smith's death. Harris had opened a fresh account at the London Joint Stock Bank. There was no obligation to give Mrs. Smith an opportunity of testing the rights of the thing. We have not put in the Stock Exchange accounts yet, which will go to explain a great deal of this. Harris carried on busi
