ness in the name of Smith up to June 50; it was stopped because Mrs. Smith came up and requested it. The name remained up at 43, Moorgate Street, for the purpose of winding up the business. I do not know whether it was wound up in February, 1905. I was con
sulted about putting up Smith's name at 27, Sun Street, that was for the purpose of continuing the winding up. There was no need for it to be continued at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. It was proper to have an address, it did not matter where, really. Bleach says he got all the books in March to destroy them. I do not know why they should have been destroyed. I accept no responsibility for that My books are in the possession of the police. I did not have my own books of account; I had the fortnightly account only. I have not kept books for 10 years, and have not got any receipts from Smith; there were none required. I paid the notes in and traced them. I never gave any receipts to Smith; no necessity. I have heard of actions brought against Herbert Smith and of actions by him. There was Leslie v. Herbert Smith; another one of Smith against Foster. I do not remember the date; if you will give me the date I will tell you where Herbert Smith was then. I do not know whether it was before Smith died. I do not know that he gave the address in that

action of 98, Thorpe Road, Forest Gate. I was not aware that it was found to be a false address. I know nothing about it. I believe the above address is Harris's. He was carrying on the business as Her
bert Smith; that is after Smith's death. I do not remember that an order for security of costs was made and not complied with and the action dismissed with costs. I do not even remember that I was sued as Herbert Smith in respect of those coats. There was an ap
plication for leave to issue. I presume I answered the affidavit in support of the application by an affidavit, if you say so. I attended to the legal documents through my solicitor; very likely I swore an affidavit that I was not a partner in nor proprietor of Herbert Smith's business. If you give me the affidavit I will tell you whether it is right or wrong. The action was settled—Smith paid the money, or Harris, I really do not know. I asked Smith to settle, and pay his debt under the issue. I have never seen the affidavit produced re Ashworth against Herbert Smith. "The fact a deposed to are within my knowledge true, and I am authorised by the defendant to make this affidavit, and am advised that the defendant has a good defence to this action." Harris ought to have been the defendant there. In regard to the sentence, "I, George Harris, etc., manager to the above-named defendant," though Smith himself had been dead a year, I was not the defendant, and Harris knew I was not Smith. In Leslie v. Smith there were some proceedings in bankruptcy, in the course of which I was asked about the action. It is true I said there that I remembered an issue being directed to try whether I was, in fact, Herbert Smith, and that I asked Smith to settle it. Smith bad been dead a year, but it was Harris I asked. I did not disclose that the original Smith was dead, because the business was being carried on. I think if a man takes the business and liabilities of Smith he becomes Smith, for the purpose of a business. The ques
tions asked were affecting Smith's business. It is true I said I first met Smith some years ago; about five. Although I said here that I had known Smith 15 years, that other matter was affecting his out
side broking operations, which began about 1900. Concerning that particular business, I said I had known him about five years. I said, "I have known him about the City, met him there. I could not tell who introduced me; he was an outside broker then." "Then" means in 1900. Twenty years ago Smith was in the tea trade; I was in the same trade. I had not seen him for 10 years before 1900; when he was in the outside broking business. That action was a blackmailing one, and I was not giving any gratuitous information to anybody. It simply referred to the, outside broking period. I also said I had last seen Smith at Moorgate Street about a year ago; that was a year before 1905. I said I had not been to Moorgate Street much lately, that I ceased going when they got attacking me in the action, that I did not think I had been there that year, and that pro
bably Smith went there after I did for all I knew. That was untrue That meant Harris, who was at 43, Moorgate Street, long after I was because I did not stop the whole time. I did not tell them durries

was the same as Smith; I was not asked. It was not assumed that I was Herbert Smith. The charge in the Foster action was not as to whether I was Herbert Smith; it was an issue as to whether I was liable for costs. In regard to the question, "When you found this charge was being made against you, you did Speak to Smith about it? Yes," that was Harris. Unless you give me the date I cannot say that I was swearing it was Smith. I do not remember to whom I spoke; if it was before October, 1903, it was Smith, if it was after it was Harris. I do not think Smith was dead at the time I was saying that. If you will give me the date I will tell you; you are making some mystery about the date. You are confusing me with the Foster and Leslie actions. Mr. Barnes has acted for me some times; not frequently—Richard Barnes. The affidavits in the name of Martin were not read out, with Richard Barnes's name on them, in my hearing, nor Harris's, unless I am deaf. I do not know that Mr. Barnes acted for the defendant in the action Leslie against Smith, nor do I know that there was an agreement to pay by instalments, and a second writ issued for failure to pay. Neither do I know that there was judgment against Herbert Smith on November 10 for £100, the defence being the Gaming Act. I do not know whether such a defence sounds honest. Mr. Barnes did not tell me anything about all this. There was seen issue against me, and a notice of bank
ruptcy served. In the trial of the issue Mr. Glover was called, one of the brokers I have mentioned. He had brought an action against me for a debt, which Herbert Smith paid (that is Harris).
Mr. Justice Lawrence. Please do not use names in that way in this court. If you mean Harris, say Harris; if you mean Smith, say Smith.

Witness. I did not do business with Adam Walker; Smith did. Walker did say before Registrar Giffard that he had been to the office and seen me, and that I was Smith. He was not believed though. It was denied by his partner, who, however, was not called. If it is there it is true that he swore I was introduced to him as Smith. I believe Alexander Robert Fraser was originally a friend of Smith's. I never saw him, and I do not think there is anybody who can be called who ever did. I believe it was intended Fraser should go into business with Smith. Smith at that time was daily at 43, Moorgate Street, being seen by Harris daily and by me several times a week. I know that bank notes out of Fraser's account have been traced into my possession. I got them from Smith—Herbert Smith—they were paid to me as part indebtedness from Smith (several amounts paid out of Fraser's account to witness were put to the latter—from April, 1903, up to July 28, 1904). These were all through Herbert Smith. I do not know why he adopted the alias of Alexander R. Fraser. I know a business in the City where there are 50 different branches in 50 different names—that is in the tea trade. The Herbert Smith busi
ness was conducted in an honest and straightforward way. The Lorn
bard Financial Corporation had a somewhat different business; it was not all on the cover system. I see no reason why H. Smith

should not have had two or more businesses conducted under different names; 2, Tokenhouse Buildings were taken by Smith on my recom
mendation.
(Friday, November 8.)

Paying in book produced shows amounts paid into my account with the London City and Midland Bank, Queen Victoria Street, from January 25 to June 28, 1906; three slips are in my writing, four in Harris's, and the remainder are in Mabel Long's and some other clerk's handwriting. On the slip of February 2, 1906, written by Long, there are resemblances in the writing to the signature of "A. R. Fraser" in the Economic Bank signature book. Cheque-book No. 344 of A. R. Fraser has eight counterfoils in my writing. I could not tell you who filled the cheques in. I was not on confidential re
lations with Harris and he did not tell me who filled those cheques up. I do not pretend to remember, but it is probable the money was wanted for certain orders when I was doing the accounts at Smith's, and I wrote the counterfoil to indicate how much was wanted from Smith's banking account, and it was drawn from the Fraser ac
count. I have never seen Fraser. On June 29, 1904, the business of Herbert Smith was closed down—cheques of £50 and £210 in July would be the settling of old business. Of £100 drawn from Fraser's account in the Economic Bank as "Stereos," £20 in notes is paid into H. Smith's account (Harris); £20 to Chalmers and Cox (Hawkee); £20 to my account at London City and Midland Bank, and £30 to my account at Farnborough. Whatever I got I got from Mr. Harris trading as Herbert Smith. (Witness admitted that a large number of accounts and several letters in Herbert Smith's letter-books were in his writing.) I was helping Smith as much as I could, and when I was there all day I have no doubt I wrote one or two letters out of those many thou
sands. He was busy on account day, and I have helped him. On December 17, 1902, cheque Montgomery £10 was paid into my ac
count; in Fraser's letter-book, p. 91, is a letter acknowledging receipt of £10 signed A. R. Fraser, with a stamp. On December 18 "Price £10" is on my paying-in slip; on the same date is letter from A. R Fraser acknowledging receipt of £10 to Price. On December 19 in my paying-in book is "S. P. Bowles £4"—letter from Fraser acknow
ledging receipt of same. "H. D. English £5" is the same. There is no, concealment about it—the names are put in my slip. I got the cheques from H. Smith, whatever they were, and they were paid into my account and marked accordingly. There is nothing to show it comes from A. R. Fraser. January 28, 1903, Price £40; February 27, S. Hynd £10; September 14, 1903, Foster Knowles £206 7s., are amounts dealt in in the same way and the paying-in slips are in Harris's writing. I accept it as much as you like. So that the man who is carrying on the business of Herbert Smith in the name of the

Lombard Financial Corporation when Herbert Smith it ill it paying £276 into my banking account and filling in my counterfoil paying-in slip in his own writing. I received £695 7s. in that way. The record was in Herbert Smith's books of the accounts due me and the payments made me. My accounts are here in my paying-in slips. My records show exactly what happened. Very likely the A. R. Fraser account on September 14, 1903, when £10 was paid in then only had a credit balance of £17 3s. 9d. When I had the £206 7s. probably H. Smith owed me more. The verification was in Smith's books. On February 19, 1906, in an old letter-book of Smith's is a letter from the "Financial Guardian" to Garnock. The previous letter is April 10, 1905, from Herbert Smith, 27, Sun Street, to Nicol, stating that "ill-health has caused me to give up business." Then follow letters from the "Financial Guardian" "p.p. H. K. Ablett, manager." From July, 1902, to June, 1904, there is £23,800 paid into my account. I have had speculative dealings on the Stock Ex
change, dealings in property and real estate, dealings in foreign stamps, and other things, by which I have made money. I have no account which will show what amount of my income from my dealings in land was during the two years from 1902 to 1904. I can tell you what they were and show you the cheques. I have obtained them on the undertaking of my solicitor to return them to the drawers. In a great number of instances I turned the cheques into notes. I have produced £11,000 worth of such cheques: a great portion of it did not go into my bank, but was turned into notes and paid to Smith or others, have not taken out how much went into my account as the profits of property dealing. It can be done. I dealt in stamps. I dealt with Messrs. Plumridge. I do not remember whether I paid the £160 in notes (produced) to Plumridge for stamps. It is very likely they came out of Alexander Fraser's account; if so I got them from Smith. I could tell pretty well what profit I made from dealing in stamps. As to the remainder of my income in those two years, amounting to £23,000, from dealing and speculating in shares, I have already said you cannot call income what appears on the debit side of the banking account. You must take both sides of the account. I might draw £10,000 for shares to-day and sell them to-morrow for £11,000, and the profit would be only £1,000. You cannot call the £10,000 income. I know of two actions brought against me in 1904, alleging that I ought to pay debts incurred in the name of Herbert Smith. I account for the drop that occurred in my account with the London City and Midland Bank from several thousands to £820 by the fact that the account was not used so much; there was no business doing—bad times. This was just about the time the Herbert Smith business was started, and that explains it; the Stock Exchange trans
actions were done through him. I had to pay or receive every fort
night. The moment the Stock Exchange dealings are shut down the account loses in volume, because there are no fortnightly pay
ments. Markets were bad, and I stopped dealing for the time being. Sometimes I have had £100,000 of stock open, and at other

times not £5, and of course that affects the turnover and the debit and credit of the bank book. It is perfect nonsense to say that the pass-book shows one's income or the business one does. I have had a turnover of £30,000 or £40,000 in the half year, but that does not show the amount of profit I am making. I have paid out £10,000 or £12,000 in one day; the turnover in the books is nothing, and only shows I have done so much business. The fallacy of the position that I may do £100,000 worth of Stock Exchange business in one account, and may have to pay or receive only £10, but the £100,000, would our den the account. The banking account shows the volume of the debits and credits, but it does not show the amount of profit. I was aware that Hawkes was conducting the business of Chalmers and Cox. I do not know whether there was a Chalmers. I never went to 2, Tokenhouse Buildings in Chalmers and Cox's time. I formerly had an office at No. 4, Tokenhouse Buildings, but gave that up in 1899 or 1900. Hawkes drafted the circulars for Chalmers and Cox. I never heard that Harris was there at all. I had nothing to do with that business. I had no dealings with Chalmers and Cox. I had dealings with Hawkes, who probably had no other business at that time. I sold him shares and opened stock with him. I have no record of my dealings with Hawkes in the buying and selling of shares. They were effected through my account with Smith. The amount of the cover was small, perhaps £50 or £100, and he dealt only once or twice. I am not going to commit myself after four years. Hawkes, as Chalmers and Cox, paid me altogether £285. If Bleach says he printed circulars for Chalmers and Cox, with altera
tions, in my handwriting, that is very likely true. I may have made notes on the circulars if Hawkes asked me. The letter addressed, "Dear Governor," is in the handwriting of Hawkes. It may have been addressed to me. "Enclose Hairbrush's Epistle"—I do not know who "Hairbrush" is—"leaving you to finish with prices of the day. Have not mentioned Mexican Proofs., as it would only lead to apologetic effusion, perhaps best left alone. If you consider they (M.P.'s) should be touched upon you can only refer to the continued stubbornness of the market in face of all our pre
dictions having been verified. We must be very careful what we say to 'Hairbrush,' as in the event of any rupture any extravagance of suggestion would be in black and white against us. Bear this in mind. Will now go on to circs. Am better, but have been very low, which don't assist one. Can come up any day you want me if you will drop a line or wire. Hope Geo. is better. He was very sadly, I thought, when I saw him Friday. Then, Jas. Monday." "Geo." I expect is Harris. The letter is evi
dently written about the circular as to Mexican Preferences. Ap
parently I have recommended Mexican Preferences and he does not agree with it, as he says, "if you continue in your idea you can refer to the continued stubbornness of the market." The following letter is in the same handwriting, "Dear Governor,—There is, as you know, a large amount of div. accumulation divisible just now, a consider
able

portion of which usually finds its way into speculative channels. Have been chewing the cud of your Canadian market, but get no for
rader. Yesterday I thought the Yank Market looked a bit like com
ing again, but it now seems to have fizzled up, as per usual. You are in a better position to feel the speculative pulse than I am, and perhaps you can suggest summit. It 's now or never, so to speak, and our rule is to play up to the div. distribution. You know, as Geo. has of course told you, that I have had a relapse, but although still confined to bed I am very much better, and hope to be up Saturday or Sunday, so that I can get to graft, any way, next week. Meantime could, if I was provided with any material, knock up a circ. Here so that no time need be lost. Kindly let me have your views on the matter as early as convenient. I see Mex. Prefs. are still wobbling; shall we ever close these accounts? Financially, as I told you last week, I am in a mournful condition. Thine, Jas. Thursday." To have my views on the circulars is exactly what Hawkes would come to me for. He would address me as "Dear Governor." When he speaks of "our role," he is referring to Chalmers and Cox. Another letter in the same handwriting it at follows: "Dear Governor, Of course I wrote Hairbrush letter in ignorance of temporary collapse in Yank Market. As this is of the usual nine days' wonder order it may simply be necessary to withhold such a letter for a reaction, which occurs in this market about every ten minutes. Same remark applies to circular, which I will nevertheless ready. I feel that we can't be too careful re Hairbrush, who may require ye 'Complete Angler' being to tomb-like silent. You are, however, playing croupier and know how the game runs. Let me know when you re
quire me in town. Thine, Jas." I do not know that I ever received these letters. I do not know what they mean. It is a very high falutin' sort of style. The reference to me "playing croupier" refers, I suppose, to his losing money with me. The next letter you cannot nut upon me, at it it addressed to Harris. "I can't say exactly when I can come up until I have seen ye Dr. to-morrow, Thursday. I see ye Yank market looks like spurting a bit, the thing in whether there it sufficient strength to hang a tale on. Of course, I do not know P.'s mind on the matter. He said something about Canadians. The changed attitude of Yanks may, however, have altered this. It is a somewhat difficult and delicate decision. Confer and advise me, as I could knock up circ. here. Will tell you when I come up, but scarcely think it will be worth while this week. Moiety of Hough's stuff looks like reaching hit margin? Thine Jim." This is a letter written by a third party in which he states that he has seen me and that I advised him that Canadian Pacific was a good bargain. I could not tell you now when "Geo." did confer with me. There are a few words in the circulars and letters produced which are in my handwriting, but that does not convince me that I got the letter addressed "Dear Governor." The circular referring to Brigh
ton "A" stock has had the date altered in my handwriting. From 1904 to 1905. In both these is the following passage: "At we write

we have what we believe to be special and important information re
garding Brighton "A" stock, which will, we are informed, see a very considerable rise in the present quotations, and of which immediate advantage should be taken to secure a quick turnover of profit before the market advances, as we are well advised will be the case." I did not write a circular and cannot say whether what was true in 1904 was also true in 1905. I altered the date, but it does not follow that it was ever used. The body of the circular shows that the current price and the quotation it altered. The date being altered, the other alterations would be consequential. As to whether it was an honest and truthful thing to say in either circular "as we write we have what we believe to be special and important information regarding Brighton 'A' stock," the first thing you have to do is to ask the person who wrote it, and secondly, you have got to find out whether it was used the year afterwards, and finally to ask the person who used it whether it was right or wrong. Supposing it was sent it might be true. How can you say it would be a pure fluke if it were? I do not know how Brighton "A" was in 1904, nor in 1905 for that matter. I will go so far as to say that all my alterations have not been accepted. I do not see anything in it likely to be dishonest at all. There is no reason why I should not have special and important information in 1905, but it does not affect me because I did not write the circular. With reference to Chalmers and Cox's circular of De
cember 12, 1903, calling attention to the position of Louisville Rail-road shares, it may be a singular coincidence that exactly the same ad
vice should be given in the following year with regard to Union Pacifics, but very likely the position was the same. I appear from the circular to have struck out Union Pacifics and put in Louisvilles, and to have made the necessary consequential alterations. A similar circular has been altered to make the observations originally applied to Louisvilles apply to Brighton "A" stock, but you cannot go so far as to say that if that were printed anew it would appear to be a cir
cular advising investment in Brighton "A" stock. You do not know what may happen before it is printed. The alterations here are to show the difference in the dividend between Brighton "A" and Louis
villes. I have not altered the circular except by altering the name of the railway and the price of the stock. As to whether it strikes me as a singular coincidence that observations originally written about an American railway should be exactly applicable to an English railway you are assuming that it is used in that form. I do not as
sume that at all. The only alteration I have made is to give the proper price and proper dividend of Brighton "A." I was probably asked to do it by Hawkes. He wanted to know what the dividend was in Brighton "A" and the price of the stock, and I have put it on here. There is no alteration whatever in the body of the circular. I do not countenance or discountenance what is in the body of the circular. I have been asked to give the quotation of Brighton "A" in the latter year, and I have put it there. I do not agree at all that in the draft letter produced the opening line "We have now opened for

your account 30 Rio Tinto shares" has been struck out by me and the following submitted, "Taking advantage of the foregoing cir
cumstances, we have thought it wise, entirely in your interests, to open for you 30 Tinto shares." It is part of a business letter, and there are one or two amendments in my handwriting. I could not possibly say now for whom these letters were intended, as there is no address. As to the phrase which occurs frequently in these circu
lars "Your interests being identical with our own," it is an entirely mistaken idea that the outside broker wants his client to lose. I have heard it stated here, but the idea is utterly ridiculous. The outside broker is only too anxious to pay his clients. It is to his interest to do so because he retains his client, at the same time making money for himself en route. If the suggestion is made here that the interest of the outside stockbroker is antagonistic to that of his client it means that if the outside broker gate £10 off his client and the client loses it he has lost a client. Surely it must be the interest of the outside broker to retain his client and to make as many more as possible. He cannot do that if every deal is antagonistic to the client. The deal must be in his favour or the relationship would not continue. The outside broker is only too, glad to draw cheques to his client in order to increase his business. It is not like the case of a bookmaker; the client does not bet, and I repeat that the outside broker generally protects himself.

Mr. Justice Lawrence. That is not part of the bargain. There is nothing in these circulars that says a word about protecting your
self.
Witness. Only, on the other, assumption, if the client loses the £10 he does not go on any more, and the broker loses him and loses his business. Well, the business would not last.

Cross-examination continued. The "Financial Guardian" was started in 1905, and my business papers were removed to 2, Token-house Buildings in 1906. I did not do any business with the "Financial Guardian," and only met people there by appointment. After that I had my own address. I only saw Ablett once or twice. He was an coldish man, and appeared to be well educated. I have heard that Harris was the man who went to the bank, not Ablett. I understood that Harris only acted for Ablett after Ablett left. Ab
lett's account with the Economic Bank is in Harris's handwriting, but Ablett may have had an account elsewhere. I assume that the sug
gestion of the prosecution is that Ablett is a mere myth, an alias for Harris. As to whether I have made any inquiries for the purposes of my defence as to where the real Ablett is (if there be a real Ablett) you should have asked "for the purpose of Harris's defence." I am not interested in it. I have never been sufficiently interested in the existence of Ablett to inquire where be could be found; it does not affect me. I have never asked Harris why he introduced somebody to me whose name he assumed. I asked Harris where Ablett was, and he told me he did not know. I did not ask him why be signed his name as "Ablett" in the books of the bank. I have beard that

Harris gave the address of 6, Clovelly Mansions. I have already denied that I asked Mrs. Strick to take in letters if they came in the name of Ablett. I did not even know where Mrs. Strick's address was Ablett has drawn cheques payable to me. There is an entry in Ablett's account of the payment to me on February 19 of £89 10s. After the business had ceased to be conducted in the name of "Harris," I believe it was conducted in the name of "George Martin." Harris never gave any reason for the change. An affidavit was sworn by Ablett on February 15, 1906, that he was carrying on the business of the "Financial Guardian," and on October 13 in the same year Martin swore that he was carrying on the business, so that the change must have been between those dates. The cheques produced payable to "C. George," and endorsed "C. George" in the handwriting of Harris are my cheques, and date from June, 1893, to September, 1906. Harris was known at the bank as "Mr. George." The cheque produced payable to "George Martin" is in my handwriting. It has never been presented. The man with whom I shared the office at 2, Tokenhouse (Buildings, is the same man who has been to my knowledge passing under different names. That does not strike me as odd. I believe he had at that time been engaged in this outside broker business. I do not know whether it is in accordance with the outside broker business that the person carrying on the business should have all those different names. It is not unknown in the out
side broker business, and not unknown in other branches of business. I was not aware that Mr. Bloomer supplied lists of addresses and did printing for the "Financial Guardian." I did not know that they were lists of people living in the country. I have not seen the lists. I do not know that there is any object in making a distinction be
tween town and country shareholders. Each individual list that you require, you require for some particular purpose; sometimes you want country ones and sometimes only town ones. I have looked through some of the exhibits and find there have been town clients. I have myself frequently sent circulars to country shareholders calling meetings, without sanding them to the town ones who would know of the meeting without a circular being sent to them. I have never sent a circular to a country investor asking him to invest money with outside brokers; therefore I cannot answer that question; I cannot answer for any third parties. I only undertook to pay for the printing done for Chalmers and Cox after that business was finished; there was no necessity for it because there was nothing owing; Chalmers and Cox paid for themselves. With regard to the suggestion that as accounts in the names of two different brokers were running simultaneously, it was necessary, in making the calculation of interest, that some one should take care that no mistake was made. We have 20 or 30 more exhibits here of contango notes which do not appear in that way, and you assume that precaution was taken on one occasion only. The whole of the documents dealing with the account of Mrs. D'Alters and others is in ray handwriting, because, as I had to make correc
tions,

I thought I would copy it out again correctly; that is all. I cannot remember that I added the letters "G. M." and "H. K. A." I have chequed the contango accounts repeatedly. I did not know there was an action of "Harper v. The Financial Guardian" in which George Martin was swearing an affidavit pleading the Gaming and Wagering Act. I do not regard outside brokers transactions as essentially gaining and wagering transactions. As to whether a person pleading the Gaming and Wagering Act is acting absolutely dis
honestly in putting forward that defence depends on the transaction. Each transaction stands on its own level. Borne may be gaming and wagering transactions. I could not answer as to whether it is a dis
honest thing to plead the Gaming and Wagering Act unless I had the whole facts before me of that particular case. I am not hare to give an opinion.

Re-examined. The returns as to my profits for the year 1902 and onwards was obtained from the banks. The amount of the accounts for the first half of 1902 is £6,629, and the balance overdrawn is £5 10s. 3d.; in the second half year there is £4,117 coming in, and there is a credit balance of £36; for the half year ending June, 1903, the amount coming in is £6,406 and the credit balance is £127. The money had been in and out. In the half year to December 31,1903, I find £8,643, of which £55 only is the balance; to June, 1904, £4,696 2s. 2d., of which £1 4s. 3d. is overdrawn; and in the final half year it is £820 2s. 6d., with £1 8s. 5d. credit balance. Cheques were not made payable to C. George on my direction or to my know
ledge. I noticed it from my pass-book, and asked Harris for the explanation I have given. Smith's letter-books contain a complete record of the business, and in every instance which has been men
tioned where there is a payment direct into my account I have ascer
tained there is a letter showing the source from which that money came. I knew of Tyler's arrest the day after it occurred and of Harris's the same day. I was arrested 16 days afterwards. I knew that letter-books were in existence showing accounts and letters in my writing. I had not concealed or destroyed any document or cheque or book of any kind whatever. On July 29, 1903, I drew from my account £400 in notes and paid it to Herbert Smith. (Witness proved a large number of payments by him into H. Smith's account.) Some of the money came from extraneous sources—moneys over and above those drawn from my bank. On October 29 I received a cheque from Turner on a real property transaction for £500 (pro
duced) which I cashed in notes and paid into Smith's account; they form part of £640 paid in on that day. On December 10, of £592 paid into Smith's account £580 was in notes; January 14, another payment of £500 in notes derived from cheque of Turner for £500 for real property. There were a large number of similar payments of which I have the cheques here. The Lombard Financial Corpora
tion (apparently carried on by Fraser) was always treated as a part of Herbert Smith's business. I had no part in the working of that business and took no share of the profits. I gave assistance to

Harris. No attempt has been made by me to destroy books. I saw nothing wrong in the continuance of Herbert Smith's business by Harris. After Mrs. Smith's visit to me in June, 1904, the H. Smith account was practically closed down—anything done after
wards was the clearing up. H. Smith had a large number of clients and a good business, as is shown by the letter-books containing up
wards of 15,000 letters. The work could not have been done without a staff; there were 40 or 50 letters a day. Harris had had a large Stock Exchange experience. The non-success of the business was due to bad markets and people not dealing so freely in the latter part of the time. With regard to my being on the voting list for 43, Moorgate Street, I had formerly had an office at 4, Tokenhouse Build
ings, and on my giving that up, the agent of a political organisation traced me as being known at 43, Moorgate Street, and put my name on the list. I did not even know of it, and never voted on it. No cheque derived from Herbert Smith was ever cashed in gold—always in notes. Those notes were never turned into gold. I had known Hawkes for a great many years. He worked for me on the "Financial Observer," and usually called me "Governor." I had helped him as I have others of my old employees—old friends. With regard to alterations of circulars, my assistance was called in to give the prices of stock, the amount of the dividend compared with the same day one year or two years before or on kindred points.

ROBERT ELLIS , clerk to Percy Ellis, stockbroker. During 1902, 1903, and 1904 my employer acted as stockbroker to Herbert Smith. I have prepared an extract from the books from December 30, 1902, to January, 1904, 28 fortnightly accounts, showing a total of stock opened during that period of £123,284. In respect of differences there was paid £4,620 6s. 6d. The stocks dealt in were mainly Rio Tintos. Atchisons, Unions, Baltimores, Southern Pacifics, and Trunk Third Preference.

Cross-examined. Mr. Percy Ellis is not here—he would know Herbert Smith. I have never seen Smith. I do not know anything about the transaction. I was not in the office at the time. By the look of the accounts Smith was more a "bull" than a "bear." I have not gone into the account to see the amount of stock actually pur
chased, or opened—part of the amount would be contangoes. Against the amount of losses paid by Smith there was £665 2s. 8d. received by him for profit.

Re-examined. At the end-May account, £15,289 is stock open; some of that may be contangoes going out and coming into the ac
count.

WILLIAM CHAPMAN , clerk to C. J. Allen, stockbroker. I have pre
pared an account of our transactions with Herbert Smith from July 29, 1903, to May 12, 1904. The largest amount open at any one time was £10,820; total amount dealt in, £98,000; actual amount paid by Smith, £1,331 12s. 7d., less £200 received. The stocks-dealt in are Steels, Unions. Atchisons, Canadas, Rio Tintos.
(Monday, November 11.)

JAMES WILKES HAWKES . I was subpœnaed by the prosecution and have been in attendance every day for a fortnight. My age is 80. I have known Perryman about 18 years and worked for him when he was on the "Financial Observer"; Harris was also working with him at that time. I remember taking some premises from a man named Dove; 2, Tokenhouse Buildings; that was for the purpose of carry
ing on the business of Chalmers and Cox. I was Chalmers and Cox, stock and share dealers—outside brokers. I composed the circulars. I have not in the ordinary composition of a circular had to ask the assistance of Perryman. I gave the orders for the printing to Bleach (the witness) and also to his father. I think Bleach arranged all the Argus work; I paid Bleach. Perryman never paid money to the Argus, as far as I know. I had control of the banking account and drew cheques. I consulted Perryman very frequently in connec
tion with the business, in reference to the stocks and market, and generally. A Mr. Watson was associated with me as partner subse
quently, when I removed to 49, Moorgate Street; that was in 1904. I gave notice to leave Tokenhouse Buildings. Mr. Dove and I did not come in contact; I always saw the managing clerk. I told the latter that Harris was going to take over the office. I could not give the exact date of that, because Harris did not take over the office at the time he negotiated with me to do so. He was to do it at Christmas, whereas it was about March when he did. I have seen Perryman occasionally at 43, Moorgate Street. I have shown him some of my circulars and he has made suggestions and alterations upon them, but I cannot say I have always acted on them; they did not always fit in with my view. I remember being ill; about which time I wrote to Perryman, seeking his advice on various stocks that I had opened, and difficulties I was in at the time. I used to buy shares from Perryman; Bonanzas, Chartered, and United Collieries, I think. I have also opened up stock with him—to protect myself. Perryman was a very large dealer I always understood, and on one or two occasions ho sold me the stock, not necessarily for delivery. I could not tell you whether I have opened up stock with anyone else, but I have an idea that I did with Harris. Perryman never came to my office. He did not have any share in the profits of Chalmers and Cox; I carried the business on myself; but, of course, he assisted me a good deal. The business is not in existence now, due to a variety of causes, want of capital and badness of business generally; the expense was too great. I have had interviews with the police on this matter. I have seen Mr. Ottaway several times, but have not had much to say to him. I really could not tell you the meaning of the phrases in some of these letters, "The Complete Angler," for instance, or "Hairbrush"; the latter appears to be the nickname of some client. There is a payment to a man named Brush in the banking account of Chalmers and Cox; I could not tell you whether that was "Herr Brush." I have tried hard to

explain what "hairbrush" means, but failed. I always called Perry
man" governor," from the old "Observer" days; he was my governor then. In regard to the phrase "I fear we cannot be too careful re hairbrush, who may require your complete angler being so tomblike silent. You are, however, playing croupier, and know how the game lies." I suppose "tomblike silence" means that I was getting no replies to my letters. I cannot say what I meant by it. I take it a croupier is one who directs the game at a gaming table; that would be my definition. I can only suppose that was when Perryman was running some stock against me and I should imagine he would be winning, I was evidently sorry I had opened the stock with him. These letters are in pencil; they were probably written in bed. I was in a good deal of pain at the time; I had to be operated upon. I have had no action brought against me in reference to Chalmers and Cox, and no complaints by the police that I am aware of. (Mr. Muir asked to be allowed to re-call Perryman before cross-examining witness, and that the latter should withdraw from court.)

C. W. PERRYMAN, recalled. Further cross-examined. (Witness read out the signature form of the Economic Bank.) The top part is in my writing; it is not my signature. "Alexander Robert Frater, mining agent, Lombard Street, as above, J. W. Hawkes," is in my writing I cannot say in whose writing "Alexander R. Fraser" is. I am not an expert in handwriting. It looks like Miss Long's; I know it is not mine. The reason I wrote that document is this: I knew the trustees of the bank, and I had a number of these forms given me for the purpose of finding customers, current account holders for the bank. The name "Hawkes" looks like mine; it is not a signature. I never saw Alexander Robert Fraser. I was told he was a mining agent by Smith. The word "personally" is not in my writing.

Further re-examined. I had not seen the above document since I wrote it until to-day. The signature Alexander R. Fraser is a little different from that in the signature book. The business of Alexander Fraser, the Lombard Corporation, was carried on with the business of Herbert Smith.

JAMES WILKES HAWKES , recalled. Cross-examined. (Witness read out the form previously read by Perryman.) I know nothing what ever about Alexander Robert Fraser, and never saw him. This form is not in my handwriting; it looks like Perryman's writing, all of it. I knew his writing fairly well. I have seen Herbert Smith at 43, Moorgate Street on various occasions; I should not say very often. I went there occasionally to see Harris and Perryman. The latter was not always there, but Harris was. I had nothing to do with drafting Herbert Smith's circulars. I fancy I spoke a good deal to Harris about starting the business of Chalmers and Cox, and I believe I mentioned it to Perryman. I opened an account with the Economic Bank for Chalmers and Cox, but I had had one previously. I opened the latter account in the name of Cox because I was trading in that name. I wanted the name of a firm; that is why I chose Chalmers and Cox; I thought it

would look better. I discussed the name with Harris, and I am rather under the impression that he suggested "Chalmers." I also discussed it with Perryman, who suggested some Exchange as a name, "The London Exchange," or something like that; but I did not like Exchanges. I should imagine the discussion took place at Moorgate Street; I should think that would be right. My memory about that time is pretty indistinct; I can remember things better 20 years ago. I drafted the circulars for Chalmers and Cox, and I rather think Perryman has altered them sometimes. I had an assis
tant in the business, Mr. Beteon, and I had a good deal of assistance from Harris. Whenever I was in any difficulty I frequently consulted Perryman. I think I have the credit of being able to write, in every sense of the word. If I remember rightly I signed the letters with a rubber stamp; my signature is inclined; to vary; not through bad habits. I signed the cheques as they were required; possibly some
times in advance, because I was away very frequently. Betson would have the cheque book, and he had instructions to hand it to Harris whenever he wanted it. Harris supervised my business when I was ill. I think he has been working with Perryman all the time I have known him. I could hardly say that handing blank cheques to Harris was the same thing as handing them to Perryman. I think there were one or two interregnums when Harris left Perry
man for a short time because of a tiff. I borrowed money from Perryman when I was short; I do not know that it would be £2 a week; more than that; I used to draw a certain sum per week. It was a loose arrangement I had with him. I had some money of my own when I started this business, which I lost; I paid a good deal out to clients. I should think I got into difficulties five or six months after I started, soon alter my illness. Watson and I had the moneys that came into the business.
To Mr. Justice Lawrence. I should think I put about £100 into the business; I had it in the bank; I had £300 or £400 about that time.

To Mr. Muir. In regard to the phrases in the letter, "complete angler," etc., and "playing croupier," a croupier is a man who rakes in the money; I feel a little clearer now about it. The letter to Mrs. A. E. R. Brush is in my handwriting. It would appear by that that all my splendid prophecies had come untrue. In regard to the letter, "We are sorry to learn you have been let in, and fear you have fallen across some black sheep. Your orders and instructions shall have our immediate attention; you will always find us prompt in our settlements. As you will have observed from our circular, our inte
rests and our clients' are identical," the broker does not necessarily lose if the client is successful, unless he is running the stock against the client; for the most part we were doing so. That letter would hardly bear much explanation. The words in the circular, "Our commission is 10 per cent. of the profits only, so that our clients' interests and our own are identical,"' would seem to suggest we were mere brokers. That is the only profit we were supposed to have

made. I could not tell you what we made apart from that. There is another letter, to Mr. Hough, in which there is a correction from 34 to 74, in my handwriting. It is all in mine. Regarding the draft circular with the paragraph, "A special note should also, we think, be made of the fact that the present existing war scare can in no way adversely affect English Rails," etc., I do not know whether it was published; I do not see anything which would lead me to sup
pose it was published. None of the letters of Chalmers and Cox's business were typed at 43, Moorgate Street. Of course, I cannot tell what Harris did when I was away ill.
Mr. Muir: Did not you realise at some period of this business that it was a swindle?.

Witness. Well, no. I did not like the business; it was too risky; there was too much anxiety for a person of my age. I did not tell Perryman it was a swindle. I did not think it was; not even now. Perryman said he thought I was a very poor outside broker. I was very good as a writer; or something to that effect. He said some
thing like, "You will never make a bucket shop keeper." I do not know why he should use that term, because there is no such thing now as a bucket shop in England; it is an American institution. You are not allowed to deal on the tape now in England. Bucket shop is rather an offensive term. I do not keep books at all; I made up my accounts on pay-sheets every fortnight. Betson kept them, as a matter of fact. They were not shown to anyone that I am aware of, Perryman did not see them; they never left Tokenhouse Build
ings and he never came there. I cannot say whether Harris saw them; very likely he did. The only book that I know Perryman kept was a Stock Exchange bargain-book. I have seen that at Moorgate Street. I could not tell you what transactions were recorded in it; those I had with him were, certainly. I should imagine Herbert Smith's were; but I know nothing of that. The contract notes, I should say, were usually made out at the end of the day; it depended on circum
stances. I made them out myself; but I have had assistance from Harris; I do not recollect having had from Perryman. In what I have told you I have come as near the truth as I could; the entire truth I have told you, as far as I can recollect. I have made and signed a statement about this business, one on August 17, witnessed by Mr. Stanier, the City Solicitor's managing clerk, and another on July 4, witnessed by Mr. Towell, another clerk. I believe I told them the truth.

(Mr. Muir commenced to read a statement, when Mr. Marshall Hall objected that he had not had a copy of this farther evidence and protested that it ought not to have been handed to the Judge. He stated that the practice seemed to be growing of handing documents up to Judges, of which copies were not handed to the other side.)
Mr. Muir explained that it had been handed of in mistake with a lot of other documents.
(Mr. Muir continued to read a statement which witness had made to the solicitors for the prosecution.)
Mr. Marshall Hall said that Mr. Muir ought to confine himself to reading what would have been evidence had the prosecution in fact called the witness.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. If you look at it you will see he has omitted a passage.

Mr. Marahall Hall. I agree. But I take the last piece he baa red—"I had nothing more to do with Perryman till about 1902," &c.—that is not evidence in that ease. This gentleman's opinions about what was going on in 1902 cannot be evidence.
Mr. Justice Lawrence, Mr. Muir is putting to the witness a statement which he made on a previous occasion; it comes within the section of the Act.

Mr. Marahall Hall. I agree, in any way, where he contradicts himself or where be has made a statement of a different nature, ha is entitled to put it; but the para
graph he has just read is not a statement of a different nature, and It is mere pre
judice.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. I do not see any prejudice.

Mr. Marahall Hall. It is this: He gives it as his opinion that they were carrying on a butineas in connection with the "Financial Observer" as a bucket shop. No witness is entitled to say that. I do not say that I see the remedy for this, but I submit it is a very serious and dangerous practice—though, of course, in the scrupulous hands of Mr. Muir it would not be abused.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. If you look at the attitude you will find it expressly authorised.
Mr. Marshall Hall. I think the word "relevant" must be read into that action. If my friend wants to use a written document he must confine himself to what would be relevant as evidence in chief.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. Certainly. He cannot put that document in; he can only ask questions upon it; and he is now calling attention to it. If the witness denies it he can then put it in.

Mr. Marahall Hall. I do press this because I want to get a decision upon it. You will see that the section in Lord Denman'e Act never contemplated the bodily putting in of the statement as evidence. (Mr. Marahall Hall read the section in Lord Denmen's Act) I do press your Lordship upon it because it is not only an objec
tion now, it is an objection of all time, and I can contemplate the most terrible abuse might arise from such a practice being adopted.
Mr. Justice Lawrence. I am afraid I cannot rule under the statute that it is not admissible.

Cross-examination continued. Perryman did not ask me shortly after
wards (after 1902) if I would start a bucket shop. I never used the term "bucket shop." He did not ask me if I would start an outside broker's business. That statement is a mistake evidently. It was some years after this Rosenberg incident that I started Chalmers and Cox. I am not responsible for what is put down there; it is put down wrongly. I ought not to have signed that statement. "We had some conversation about starting an outside broker's business"—that was a long time after this incident. I rather think Perryman said that Dove had offices to let at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. I think he said he would assist me, not "pay everything, including rent, printing, etc." If I said that, I should not have done so. I suppose the statement must have been read over to me. I should think I said, "Harris was, I believe, present on this occasion, and I believe he knew what the arrangement was." I did not take the office under Perryman's instructions. It might be true that Perryman said he would overhaul the circulars. It is true that he suggested various titles under which I might trade. When I suggested Chalmers and Cox, I should have said "Harris and Co." Perryman gave me an idea of what stock to write about. I started the business with the assistance of Perryman and Harris.

He did not think my bank was good enough, and advised me to go to Lloyd's Bank, which I did. Harris was supposed to be secretary. Harris did not introduce me to Lloyd's Bank, I went there myself. The manager did not appear to know him, the account was not opened there, and I was introduced by Ernest to the London Trading Bank, where I opened the account as Chalmers and Cox, giving my name as "James Wilkes Cox," 2, Tokenhouse Buildings. Perryman only had the control of money in connection with stocks that I had opened with him. If I said the contrary I ought to have been more careful. Harris had the cheque-book, not Perryman, and Harris filled the cheques up. Towell read my statement to me, and I signed it. I may have been not careful enough in making corrections in it. I generally had £2 a week from Harris, sometimes £3. I do not think it is true to say that Perryman had the whole of the money—there was none to have; it all went in expenses. Practically, I was a weekly servant. I paid the money or cheques into the banking account, but sometimes I handed banknotes or postal orders to Perry
man—I nearly always owed him money. On one or two occasions he may have drafted a letter or portion of a letter. I have no recol
lection of letters being typed at 43, Moorgate Street. I knew the business of Chalmers and Cox was not being conducted properly, and I did not like it; I thought there was a great deal of sharp practice, and that Perryman had put me into a very dangerous position—actions being brought against ma through acting on his advice. I will not swear that I did not say to Towell that Perryman said, "You will never make a bucket shop keeper," but I do not think he used the word "bucket shop." The pencil letters produced were written by me while ill in bed. I do not think the contract notes were made out by Perryman—I consulted Harris about them. It was understood the business of Chalmers and Cox must be carried on on proper lines, and that, if people won, they were to be paid. Watson is dead—he had the Chalmers and Cox papers.

Re-examined. Ottaway asked me to go to the City Solicitor. No threat of any kind was made to prosecute me. Ottaway found me through Dove. The evidence I have given this morning is, as far as I know, correct. I left a lot of waste-paper at 2, Tokenhouse Buildings.

WILLIAM STAPLEFORD , 57, Holborn Viaduct, 15th Middlesex Rifle Volunteers. I met Tyler in South Africa, and, on the recommenda
tion of the commander, he was made acting secretary of the battalion, in which I was an officer and member of the finance committee, handled the whole of the funds, and, at the disbandment, received a hearty vole of thanks for his excellent conduct. He then became secretary to my firm, William Stapleford and Co., Cape Town, had £5,000 a month through his hands for 18 months, gave the highest satisfaction, and was then put in charge of the Johannesburg branch until the winding-up of the business, which he conducted perfectly satisfactory. I formed a very high opinion of him. He moved in the best military circles in the colony.
GEORGE LONDON , 19, Eastcheap. In 1905-6, Tyler did a great deal of work for me. I found him a person of undoubted honesty and integrity.
SAMUEL JOHN FOX NEWBURY , Army and Navy Stores. I have known Tyler 45 years, from his schooldays. He is a person of the highest character and integrity.
(Tuesday, November 12.)

Verdict.
Each prisoner Guilty on all counts, Perryman being the instigator throughout, and Tyler the least to blame.

Inspector
OTTAWAY , in referring to the history of Perryman from 1884, said that while he was a member of the Sports Club it was alleged—Mr. Marshall Hall protested against statements where "it was alleged." Mr. Justice A.T. Lawrence said he was afraid he must receive it and that he must be trusted to know the meaning of it.

The Inspector (continuing) said it was alleged that Perryman attempted to swindle a bookmaker by backing a horse after knowing the result of the race, and it was decided to expel him, but that decision was reconsidered. Soon after he started a bucket-shop business, and later on in the year promoted a bogus concern in which the public were defrauded. In 1890 he was expelled from the National Liberal Club in consequence of his connection with a gold mining company which was exposed by the "Financial News," who were sued by Perryman in the Queen's Bench Division, when the jury found the company to be a swindle. He was subsequently at this court sentenced for libel to two months' imprisonment as first
class misdemeanant. Numerous instances were given by witness as to the shady transactions in which Perryman had been mixed up, and he stated that many complaints had been received in connection with the present business.
There had been no convictions against Harris or Tyler.

Mr. Marshall Hall asked the Judge to state a ease on the point of the reception of the whole of Hawkes' statement, which he, Mr. Hall, considered had prejudiced the jury. Mr. Justice Lawrence said he could not state a case on that.

Sentences: Perryman,
four years' penal servitude; Harris,
18 months' hard labour; Tyler,
nine months' hard labour.
The jury commended Inspector Ottaway for his efficient conduct of the case.
BEFORE MR. JUSTICE A.T. LAWRENCE.
(Monday, November 4.)

div0.p:
GRIFFIN, Leonard Brown, convicted on his own confession, before Mr. Justice Bucknill, on September 14, 1905, for publishing a criminal libel concerning William John Mann, and released on his own recognisances in £500, and an undertaking not to repeat the offence, was brought up for judgment to show why he should not for
feit his recognisances on account of a repetition of the offence with which he was originally charged.
Sir Charles Mathews prosecuted. Mr. Harold Morris appeared for the prisoner.

E.B. RODWAY, Mann and Rodway, solicitors, practising at Trow
bridge. Mr. William Mann is my partner in that business. I re
ceived a letter which purports to be addressed from the General Post Office, Southend, Essex, in an envelope dated January 24, 1907. I also received a letter addressed to me from 54, Shaftesbury Avenue, dated February 17. I believe I received it the next day. I received the telegram produced on Saturday night, September 7, and a letter of September 8 beginning, "I am surprised that such an illustrious snob," on the Tuesday, I think. I received all those from the pri
soner.

WILLIAM JOHN MANN I am a solicitor of the firm of Mann and Rodway, at Trowbridge, where I hold several positions of an official character. The prisoner is my wife's nephew. My wife's Christian name is Julia, but she is commonly called "Dolly" by her sisters. Before the prisoner's arrest there was some correspondence between the prisoner's mother and her sister with regard to the prisoner. The prisoner was convicted on his own confession of libel on Septem
ber 14, 1905. In my presence he then gave the undertaking to Mr. Justice Bucknill which has been read. That, however, seems to have been followed up, in December of 1906, by the false allegation with regard to how it was that the prisoner's elder brother died of starvation in Canada. I sent a copy of the telegram to the prisoner's mother and made inquiries. In January, 1907, I learnt that this course of persecution had commenced afresh. I received the letter of March 19 from the postman and handed it to my wife; she read it in my presence. The whole of it is in the prisoner's handwriting and also the envelope. I was the recipient of a form of typewritten notice circulated on March 11. That came to me, although it was addressed to "Mr. M. Mann." The letters produced are in the pri
soner's handwriting, also the postcard addressed to the proprietor of the "Wiltshire Times."
His Lordship intimated that he would consult with Mr. Justice Bucknill on the subject.
Mr. Morris asked that the mental condition of the prisoner might be inquired into while he was under remand, to which his Lordship assented.
(Tuesday, November 12.)
Dr. Scott, medical officer, Brixton Prison, said that prisoner was suffering from chronic alcoholism, but could not say he was insane.
He was sentenced to Eighteen months in the second division.
